speaker: The Speaker
theText: The answer to the hontee has duly reported to Parliament: DevelopmentWednesday, 1 June 2005 ----Principal for a Day for a Day-a program run in New South Wales, and perhaps in other states, whereby community, business and opinion leaders, and politicians are invited to spend a day, or a portion thereof, with the principal of a public school in order to gain first-hand insight into the current state of public education-its challenges and its achievements. Last year I visited the Matraville Soldiers Settlement School, a primary school in the electorate of Kingsford Smith with a school population drawn from many cultural backgrounds, many of the parents having recently arrived in Australia, including a number of Aboriginal children too. I was taken by the high level of care shown by staff, particularly to kids with physical or mental challenges. In past times, these kids would have been isolated in institutions. Nowadays they are embraced as full members of the school community. The school supported these kids, as well as other kids in the school, and worked closely with families to get the best out of the kids at this important stage of their education. I commend the principal and the staff for their untiring efforts at Matraville. This year, I had the opportunity to visit Randwick Boys High and again was struck by the generous spirit and obvious dedication shown to students by teaching staff and by the very real achievements of the student body. Numbered amongst them were outstanding athletes, kids with fine academic records and those making real contributions in art, music, science and, more generally, to the life of the school community. Given the recent patterns of curriculum choices we have seen in Australia, where there has not been a great emphasis on learning in science and technology, I was particularly pleased to see the science labs full and humming with senior students. Naturally, I enjoyed the performance of the composite orchestra, made up of a string section, the local band and students from the collegiate school next door, Randwick Girls High. Playing together, they made absolutely wonderful sounds. The measurable benefits of learning a musical instrument, the foundational role music plays in our culture and, of course, the way playing music with other people brings the school community together, cannot be underestimated. Principals have a range of complex responsibilities as they lead and inspire their schools. At Randwick Boys High and Matraville Soldiers Settlement, I saw their good efforts first hand and I commend them to the House. speaker: Mrs May (Mcpherson) (9.32 Am)
theText: With just two words last Friday-‘You’re in’-thedisappointment last year and the commitment of a small band of dedicated individuals had delivered a rugby league team back to the Gold Coast. The excitement was infectious. The news spread very quickly throughout the city and the celebration was on. I am told that Michael Searle and his mentor, Paul Broughton, shook hands and then hugged each other. There were no words. These two special men had ridden an emotional rollercoaster for nearly six years. They both had a dream to deliver a National Rugby League team back to the Gold Coast. They dared to dream and the dream had become a reality. The hard work is not over. We have less than two years to put together a team that we can all be proud of. This will be a team that our entire Gold Coast community can get behind. It will be a competitive team. It will be driven by our local community, by the young players in the junior ranks who will now have a pathway to strive for-a pathway that will lead them into the national competition and even to aspire to representing their state or their country at international level. I have had the opportunity of working with the Gold Coast bid team for nearly two years. Today, I want to pay tribute to the professionalism, commitment and credibility of two men who drove this bid and the dream: first, to the managing director, Michael Searle, an exceptional young man who has driven this bid with tenacity and belief and, second, to Paul Broughton, a man who is passionate about the game of rugby league-one of life’s gentlemen who never gave up the dream. At 74, Paul was the inspiration to us all to keep going until the dream was realised. These two men were supported by Ian Buchanan, who drove the media, worked tirelessly to ensure the message to the fans was the right message and put the positive spin on every step through the journey; by Geoff Smith, the legal brains, the man who ensured the legal paperwork was done, whose excitement last Friday was unbelievable; and by Rob Molhoek, now a Gold Coast City councillor, a man who is committed to the youth of Gold Coast City and believes the youth will benefit enormously with a career pathway in rugby league. These five men were the driving force behind the consortium. Jim Raptis, Steve Burns and I came on board around two years ago and lent our different areas of expertise to the bid team. We have all enjoyed our roles and feel very proud to be part of this winning combination of people. Let the planning begin for 2007. Central Queensland Air Services Ms LIVERMORE (Capricornia) (9.35 am)-I regret that I am here once again to raise the matter of a further reduction in the services offered to Central Queenslanders by Qantas. As from today, 1 June, Qantas has cut its Jetstar services to and from Rockhampton by 50 per cent. It is now not possible to fly with Jetstar and spend the day in Rockhampton or, going the other way, a day in Brisbane. Jetstar customers from Central Queensland are forced to stay overnight in Brisbane, which of course negates the advantage of a cheap airfare. This 50 per cent reduction in Jetstar services will also have a very serious impact on the Central Queensland tourism industry. Qantas made much of the introduction of its low-priced Jetstar service to Rockhampton. The House may recall that I said previously that it appeared to me that Qantas was forcing the people of Central Queensland to use Jetstar to give the new airline a revenue base while it MAIN COMMITTEE established itself on the main trunk routes. Now, as Jetstar is established between the capital cities, we see Qantas withdrawing those Jetstar services from Central Queensland. I see that as proof positive of the Qantas policy of abandoning regional Australia. It is true that Qantas is making much of its intention to replace the Jetstar service with the propeller-driven Dash8 aircraft. But let me give you an example of what this really means to the people of Central Queensland. One of my constituents was booked to fly from Rockhampton to Cairns on this small Qantas aircraft, which goes via Mackay and Townsville on its way to Cairns. When this constituent learned that in fact he would be in Mackay on the day of his departure, he rang Qantas and said that he would now like to board in Mackay. Of course this would give Qantas the opportunity to sell that seat to Mackay to someone else. However, my constituent was advised by Qantas that he could not do that unless he paid a $33 re-routing fee and purchased a new full fare ticket to Cairns at a cost of $457. Another constituent, who was trying to attend the same conference in Cairns, simply gave up trying to go because of the difficulties in trying to find a flight that would get him there in a reasonable time. Yet another constituent of mine, who travels regularly for business to and from Rockhampton, has told me that he purchased a frequent flyer cabin bag to ensure that he did not have a problem walking onto planes with carry-on luggage. He was boarding a Dash8 in Brisbane last Thursday when he was advised by Qantas that the Qantas cabin bag was in fact too big and he had to check it in-a great inconvenience. He was advised that the bag was okay on a jet but not on the smaller Qantas planes that service Rockhampton. Mr Deputy Speaker, you really have to wonder whether Rockhampton was better serviced in the 1960s by TAA and the good old Fokker Friendships than it is today by Qantas. It would seem that the best friend that Virgin Blue Airlines has is Qantas management, with these kinds of decisions that really penalise regional Australia. Water Re-use Heritage) (9.38 am)-I want to talk about water reuse on the Mornington Peninsula, in the Westernport area and in Australia more generally. Firstly, I would like to welcome yesterday’s decision by the Victorian government to finally complete and launch the water retreatment program for Cranbourne and associated areas, which is known as the Eastern Irrigation Scheme. This scheme will deliver approximately five billion litres of water to golf courses, market gardens and parks and gardens in the eastern area of Melbourne. In my electorate of Flinders, farmers in Cranbourne South, Five Ways, Devon Meadows and Clyde will have access to high-grade treated water and they can use that to save costs, provide volume and take pressure off the environment. All of those things together make this a tremendously important project-overdue but important. Secondly, this proposal, the Eastern Irrigation Scheme, deals with about three per cent of the waste water discharged from the Gunnamatta outfall, which is about three per cent of 150 billion litres a year. So effectively it prevents any further increases. It does not really deal with the underlying question. To solve that, we have to aim for much higher than the states’ proposal of 20 per cent reuse. There is no question, as we look all around Australia today, that we have to work towards a total reuse policy for water. It is reasonable, it is achievable and it is the way of the future. At Gunnamatta the problem continues. Over 150 gigalitres, or 150 billion litres, of waste water every year are being discharged right on the shoreline. It is unacMAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Hunt (Flinders
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment andceptable, it is environmentally damaging, it is a health risk and it is a total waste of a valuable resource. I recommit myself to working towards a zero outfall for Gunnamatta. I am delighted to say that I have been working with the Prime Minister’s office, with the Deputy Prime Minister and others on precisely that objective, and I believe that there may be something from the Commonwealth in the near future. Thirdly, at the national level, we have to work towards 100 per cent water recycling nationwide. The position in Sydney of two billion litres of waste water at the raw sewage level and almost 400 billion litres of waste water at the primary level being discharged into the sea is an utter disgrace. Across Australia we need a national ocean outfall strategy which will achieve the ending of ocean outfalls by 2025 and the full recycling of water. I am delighted that yesterday was a beginning. (Time expired) University Funding Ms GRIERSON (Newcastle) (9.41 am)-Today is the National Tertiary Education Union’s national day of action protesting the assault on university funding and the impact of that on staff since the Howard government decided to rip out $5 billion worth of funding. The latest insult to our tertiary sector is the threat to withhold a further $838 million if staff are not moved onto individual contracts. I am very fortunate to count staff at the University of Newcastle amongst my dearest friends and amongst those whom I admire most for their contribution to our society. This week staff at Newcastle university have seen what a proposed job loss of 439 full-time equivalent jobs will look like. In this very difficult phase, I register my strong support for them and regret that they are suffering quite markedly. I have faith that their professionalism will cushion students, but there is a real risk of a crisis in confidence. I again call on the government to assist the Hunter region to absorb this economic and human loss. It is estimated that the economic cost to our region will be greater than $100 million per year. A recent study showed that our university contributes nearly $650 million a year in gross output plus $215 million in salaries. So it will be felt very strongly by our region with the flow-on effect of another 150 jobs lost. The government shows very little sympathy, but certainly our region deserves and should demand some assistance. Our labour market is a lot thinner than those of cities like Sydney. That was recently quantified by Professor O’Neill, who said that our labour market vulnerability is such that, for the lower Hunter to have the same job-to-population ratio as Sydney, it would have to create 73,000 additional jobs immediately. We always feel economic shifts much more strongly. In 2005 in the Hunter, the average total income per annum per wage and salary earner is only approximately $43,000-not exactly prosperous or rolling in cash. I understand that the university would like to manage this change very quickly. I am sympathetic to its desire to get back in the black; I understand that. But the costs of getting this wrong are huge-huge for the region and huge for the people involved in the industry. At our university we do not just turn out units of production; we actually solve some of the problems of the world, some of the problems of Australian society. At the moment, groundbreaking research is being done in obesity, prostate cancer, premature births, family relationships, the rural GP shortages, nanotechnology, engineering, the Jameson Cell-some landmark research values benefiting all. It is disgraceful that our region is left to handle this crisis by itself. It is disgraceful that universities are compromised by every decision this government has made. (Time expired) MAIN COMMITTEE South West Indoor Aquatic Centre Dr SOUTHCOTT (Boothby) (9.44 am)-Australia has had an outstanding record in international swimming, going right back to the days of Freddie Lane winning a gold medal at the Paris Olympics in 1900, and from ‘Boy’ Charlton, Dawn Fraser and Murray Rose right through to our current champions: that great crop of women sprinters from Brisbane; Ian Thorpe; and Grant Hackett. But I rise on an issue of local importance to my electorate-that is, the state of South Australia has no FINA-standard pool. South Australia is not able to host any national swimming championships. We are not able to host a world masters championships. We have not had a FINA pool for some time. Even a state like Tasmania has three to four FINA-standard pools. The South West Indoor Aquatic Centre is a project that has been around for some time. It has been proposed by state governments of both political stripes-the Olsen government and the Rann government-to be built at the Domain in Marion, in my electorate. In February 2004, it was proposed that this be done through a public-private partnership. The Minister for Recreation, Sport and Racing, Michael Wright, announced this in a media release. Late in 2004, approaches were made to me by the Marion council to see if there was any possibility of federal assistance. I made the point to them that swimming pools are not normally an area of federal responsibility but that I would see what I could do. I helped the Marion council to make a submission as part of the 2005 budget. We got a tremendous hearing from the Minister for the Arts and Sport, Senator Rod Kemp, and the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Nick Minchin. Although there was no federal funding, I will be continuing to push for this project. Having said that, I am disappointed that the state government is using this as an opportunity to further delay a project which has already been delayed for three or four years. There has been a sign at the site of this proposed pool since October 2001. It is now being said that what was always planned as a state-local government project will only go ahead contingent on federal funding. I will be doing what I can, but I feel akin to someone who has gone in to help a drowning person, only to be pulled in as well. (Time expired) Bittersweet Freedom: Memories of Liberation 1944-45 Peter Cosgrove opened a very interesting exhibition, at which I was present, called Bittersweet Freedom: Memories of Liberation 1944-45, at the Jewish Holocaust Museum and Research Centre in Elsternwick in Victoria, in my electorate. I congratulated Major General Cosgrove on the fact that, in concluding his very important leadership of the Australian Defence Force, he had taken time to come down and open the exhibition. The exhibition is open to the public, and I would urge members of the public to go and see it. The exhibition is produced by the museum’s curator, Jayne Josem. It basically consists of video interviews with people who were liberated by the American, British or Soviet forces. It also includes major works by Australian war artists of the time who were serving with the British forces and who, witnessing some of the camps that were liberated, felt that simple photographic evidence of what they were seeing was not necessarily an accurate way of portraying things. They felt it necessary to give vent to their art. One of the artists felt that no-one MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Danby (Melbourne Ports) (9.47 Am)
theText: On the weekend before last, Major Generalwould believe what he was drawing and therefore took it upon himself to do a photographic copy of every painting that he had prepared for that exhibition. I said to the large crowd at the exhibition opening that I congratulated Major General Cosgrove on being there representing the sort of tolerance and decency of the Australian armed forces that is typical of Australia. I congratulated him on providing for the people in the audience-many of whom have made successful lives in Australia during the 60 years since the end of the Second World War-a continuum from Sir John Monash right through to himself. The exhibition by the Jewish Holocaust Museum and Research Centre is to be commended. It underlines again the tragedy and the importance of the great victory of the Second World War. Veterans Grants service, sacrifice and suffering of our veterans, what they lived through and what some of them are still living through to defend our way of life. It is important that we pay due respect to their service, but in practical ways, so I was very pleased to announce a series of funding packages for veterans groups in the Hinkler electorate. In recent weeks, I announced a $3,480 Saluting Their Service grant to the Elliott Heads and District Ratepayers and Residents Association to help them enhance the Submarine Lookout Memorial. From a small headland and timber tower at Elliott Heads, civilian coast watchers looked out for Japanese submarines in World War II, a very practical way of assisting the war effort. I have just had the pleasure of telling the Gayndah RSL sub-branch that they will be receiving a $17,348 veteran and community grant to install air conditioning in the RSL hall and help set up a drop-in centre for local veterans. This is a new and very important focus for Central Burnett veterans. The Bundaberg sub-branch of the Vietnam Veterans Association, of which I am patron, also received two veteran and community grants totalling $7,406 to fund outings and buy a photocopier so that they can produce their own newsletter. The Bundaberg and District Korean War Veterans group received a $2,500 grant to fund bus trips to reduce social isolation for veterans and their spouses. All these projects are worthy of government support. I am fortunate that as the federal member I get to attend a wide range of commemorative functions from the Rats of Tobruk day to East Bundaberg state school’s marvellous pre ANZAC Day commemoration in their school grounds. I always make a point of attending as many ANZAC Day services as possible. This year I managed to make it to Bundaberg’s dawn service, the Rosedale dawn service, the Boyne Island-Tannum Sands RSL’s morning service, the Gladstone citizens’ ceremony, and the Burnett Heads ceremony in the afternoon. My wife, Margaret, also lent strong support by representing me at services that I could not attend. She attended the Bargara dawn service this year and the Bundaberg citizens’ service. By funding memorials and commemorative events and community based activities for veterans, we are honouring the actions of those who served our country. Although our gestures can never fully compensate veterans for their experiences, it is important that we do what we can and show that we care. New South Wales Working Women’s Centre Ms OWENS (Parramatta) (9.53 am)-The New South Wales Working Women’s Centre provides an invaluable service to people in Sydney, including in my electorate of Parramatta. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (9.50 Am)
theText: There are simply no words adequate to describe theIt provides legal advice to women in the workplace, particularly on their rights in the workplace. It has been providing this service for the last 11 years. Yet at this point, in the first week of June, DEWR has once again failed to assure its funding for the next financial year, which is 3½ weeks away. The centre is once again in crisis, as it is at this time every year, due to the lack of advice on its funding position for the following year. Is it going to be receiving any funding? If so, how much? When will it be told? Should its staff look for other jobs? Should it plan to shut its doors, give notice on leases and plan the garage sale? Will its clients be left in an increasingly unfriendly work environment without its support? If the government finally does decide to fund the centre and finally tells it, will the government be even vaguely aware that a small group of people at this time of year every year risk their own financial security by hanging on and keeping the centre open without any idea of its future? Even more importantly, given that the government is ripping away well-known and tested support structures for the most disadvantaged workers, the majority of which are women, will the government assist workers to deal with this changing environment by increasing the funding to the centre to a respectable level? Is the government even vaguely aware of, let alone concerned about, the position that our valuable community based infrastructure is placed in at this time every year when funding decisions are made this late? Is this lateness of decision a case of incompetence, a display of power and arrogance or just a general lack of care about an extremely important community organisation? Does the government even know if it will be giving any funding post-June, let alone the level of funding? The centre has endured real reductions in funding levels over the last 11 years. Given that women are the most disadvantaged in the workplace, receiving lower salaries and being far more likely to be working in casual and unskilled positions, the advocacy role of the centre is essential and growing. Yet, while the demand for the service is growing, financial support is not. The initial allocation that established the centre in the 1993-94 budget was $297,062. It has dropped in real terms by 37 per cent, to around $240,000. Yet, since 2000 alone, the centre has received a 70 per cent increase in clients and expects that trend to continue with the new industrial relations reforms. Despite staff reductions in 1999, the service to clients is quite extraordinary. The centre operates a telephone advisory service that opens three days a week. Staffing is at a 3.1 full-time equivalents but with over 20 voluntary staff. (Time expired) Sea King Helicopter Accident which claimed the lives of nine of our serving personnel, there was a tremendous outpouring of grief, none more so than in our local community of the Shoalhaven in my electorate of Gilmore. In one fell swoop, this tragedy took away four of our extended family. Four members of the crew were from No. 817 Squadron, whose home station is HMAS Albatross at Nowra Hill. It is difficult to describe the emotion that was being freely expressed at the time, as each and every one of us approached the news with different feelings. I can say that I have not seen such a reaction from a community in all my days. The four were Lieutenant Matthew Goodall, Lieutenant Paul Kimlin, Lieutenant Jonathan King and Leading Seaman Scott Bennet-all fine upstanding young Australians taken at the prime of their lives in their service to humanity. Of the four, Leading Seaman Bennet had a young family-a wife and two children-whose family home was in Tomerong, near the shores of Jervis Bay. It was the 31st MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mrs Gash (Gilmore) (9.56 Am)
theText: After the 2 April helicopter crash on the island of Niasyear of his life. I attended his funeral, which was held at HMAS Albatross. The funeral was attended by several hundred people, many of whom did not know him, but such was the sense of family felt by the community that they grieved equally. It was a very moving occasion, and its impact will be felt for quite some time. Shortly after we received the news that four of our own had gone down, we made available condolence books so that local residents could express their feelings. A similar book was made available at the chambers of the Shoalhaven City Council and at the Navy base, and the book will be given to the Navy at HMAS Albatross. Reading the entries is a bittersweet experience-on one hand deep sadness, yet at the same time extreme pride that we shared a moment together. They are brief statements, awkwardly written in some cases, but genuine in their sympathy and gratitude. They are also a symbol of the bond that has been formed between residents and those in the garrison of HMAS Albatross who have been with us for over 60 years. Every day, in some little way, we have become accustomed to seeing these Defence personnel around us, whether it be in their uniforms as they go about their daily business or as we hear the drone of the Sea Kings and other aircraft flying in and out of the air base. They are quietly in our everyday lives. I am glad we have the Navy with us: no better tenant can you find. But the four from No. 817 Squadron who perished are not the first peacetime casualties for Nowra and, sadly, probably will not be the last. Next to the general cemetery at Nowra is a neat and well-kept cemetery. It is the naval cemetery and has interred there a number of other naval personnel who died in the service of their country. It is a special place, with each tombstone having its own story to tell. In preparing for war, our servicemen and servicewomen undertake demanding tasks, sometimes with great personal risk and most times unseen. We should not need a tragedy like this to remind us of their contribution. We should be forever appreciative of their service and give them every support we can, and looking after the family of Leading Seaman Bennet in Gilmore is one such way. Bankstown Airport tence. It will govern the activity at Bankstown Airport for the next 20 years. The people of Bankstown who worked with me to achieve the key objective-that is, to stop 737 jets from being able to use Bankstown Airport-have won an enormous victory. But there is still more work to do. A noise management plan needs to be put into place. The fundamental problem in regard to noise management is that more freight aircraft will be operating out of Bankstown Airport-and there will probably be more at night. The extension of the runway by 200 metres means that planes can be more fully laden and will be flying lower and closer to people in Condell Park and associated suburbs. Logically, that means that the noise impact will therefore be greater. I call upon the management of Bankstown Airport Ltd to ensure that there is proper and full community consultation in regard to this and that the lives of people are not destroyed by inappropriate noise from Bankstown Airport. agreed to on 30 May 2005, the time for members’ statements has concluded. theText: Order! In accordance with the resolutionCognate bills: Second Reading Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Costello: That this bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Swan moved by way of amendment: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for a Budget which: (1) delivers grossly unfair tax relief which favours the highest income earners at the expense of ordinary Australian families; (2) ignores the crippling effect of punishingly high effective marginal tax rates on workforce participation; (3) imposes harsh conditions on the income of the most vulnerable members of the community; (4) fails to invest in skills and infrastructure disregarding repeated warnings from the RBA and OECD about skills shortages and infrastructure bottlenecks; (5) exposes Australians to the risk of higher interest rates as a result of capacity constraints and escalating economic imbalances; (6) predicts a significantly slowing rate of real GDP growth to below the Australian long-term average and considerably below world GDP growth; (7) confirms continuing unsustainable current account deficits into the future; (8) predicts a continuing increase in Australia’s foreign debt; (9) predicts import growth to exceed export growth; and (10) contains a proposed Future Fund which is focused on offsetting the superannuation liability of Commonwealth employees at the expense of sensible long-term investment in vital infrastructure”. Dr SOUTHCOTT (Boothby) (10.01 am)-I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak in the debate on the 2005 budget. This is the Treasurer’s 10th budget. It is the eighth budget this government has delivered which has been in surplus. A most important part of this budget is the $21 billion in tax cuts which represents, for the second time, a very significant extension of the threshold for the top marginal rate and for the second highest marginal rate. When we introduced the new tax system in 1998 we were able to ensure that everyone on incomes below $50,000 was on a marginal rate of 30c in the dollar. At that time, 80 per cent of taxpayers were on incomes below $50,000. But we were never able to implement the tax cuts we had promised because the Senate would not allow us to do so. Last year we were able to take advantage of the Leader of the Opposition at the time, Mark Latham, who had previously made a number of comments about the fact that the top marginal rate was cutting in at an income which was too low, and we were able to increase the threshMAIN COMMITTEE old for the top marginal rate to $80,000. The budget measures will now increase the threshold for the top marginal rate to $125,000. When you find that the steelworkers in Port Kembla are paying 48½c tax in every extra dollar they earn in overtime, you realise that our top marginal rates are cutting in at incomes which are far too low. One million Australians are living and working overseas. Many of these people will be looking at where the top marginal rate cuts in and this will be an encouragement for many of our best and brightest to return to Australia to work under a tax regime which is not so punitive. The welfare to work changes are another very important part of this budget. Our unemployment rate of 5.1 per cent is the lowest it has been since November 1976. As Australia’s population ages over the next 20 or 30 years, we are not going to see the growth in the work force that we have traditionally seen. It is going to be more and more important to make sure, not only for our overall economy but also for individuals, that those who can find a pathway into work are able to do so, because it leads to a much more rewarding life. The budget also contains a number of initiatives related to boosting skills. Because the economy has now been expanding for 13 years and because unemployment is now so low we are seeing a number of skills shortages emerging in the Australian economy. Because of the 13 years of economic growth we are also seeing shortages in unskilled labour. I am very pleased that we are increasing the skilled migration program by 20,000 places. This means that if you have skills which are recognised by Australia you can migrate to Australia from anywhere in the world. The budget forecasts a growth over the next year of three per cent. This also reflects the fact that our export prices are at a record high. Australia now has the best terms of trade since 1974, particularly for iron ore and coal, and this has been very significant for what our exports are earning. As I said, unemployment, at 5.1 per cent, is the lowest since November 1976. It can go lower, but it will only go lower with changes to workplace relations and a more flexible labour market. The government is also looking at ways that it can increase the participation of people in their late 40s and 50s and encourage them back into the workplace. Government debt has decreased from $96 billion 10 years ago, almost 19 per cent of GDP, to just $6 billion in this budget. There are very few countries that have wiped out their government debt. A couple of years ago we had a debate about whether we should maintain the debt market for Commonwealth government securities. A decision was made that it would be maintained. We will now be putting future surpluses away into our future fund, which means that the superannuation liabilities which have previously been unfunded will be covered. There is a cash surplus in this budget of $8.9 billion, roughly one per cent of GDP. Compare this with the OECD average of budget deficits of three per cent of GDP. Australia’s position by contrast is much, much stronger. There has been comment on yesterday’s news about the current account deficit and Australia’s foreign debt. There are a couple of points that need to be made on this. First of all, Australia has a floating exchange rate. If people believe that our current account deficit or our level of foreign debt is unsustainable, it will be reflected in the exchange rate. The exchange rate currently is very strong on the trade-weighted index and also against the United States dollar at about US76c. The other point to make is that, because we have had government budget surpluses over the last eight years, the current account deficit largely reflects private savings and investment deMAIN COMMITTEE cisions. As the OECD Economic Survey of Australia-2004, released in February 2005, states, because we have few distortions in the economy: ... private sector savings and investment decisions are likely to be efficient, with capital flows reflecting informed decisions about relative investment opportunities. Moody’s has rated us ‘Aaa’ and Standard and Poor’s has given us an AAA rating. The banking system is in good shape and the financial position of firms and individuals is in good shape. The government’s share of net external debt is very low. Government debt, as I said previously, is very low-it is less than one per cent of GDP at $6 billion. It is just extraordinary and one of the lowest in the OECD. I again quote from this year’s OECD economic survey: This places Australia in a comparatively better position than most other countries to respond to future economic shocks. To preserve this favourable position, the authorities should continue to ensure that the government does not add to aggregate external financing requirements. Put simply, we should not be running up budget deficits; we should be, as we have been, running up budget surpluses. The key theme of the 2004 federal election was, ‘Who do you trust to run Australia’s $800 billion economy?’ The mood of the Australian people at the moment is that they got that decision right. One of the things I find in the community is that people actually reflect on what might have been had Mark Latham become Prime Minister. After a few chuckles and so on people do reflect that it was a very close call but that they got the decision right. Our message was that it does take a lot of discipline and experience to run the Australian economy. We saw that the Labor Party’s approach would be to give into narrow sectional interests ahead of jobs and the economy. Nowhere was that better demonstrated than in Tasmania, where you had the extraordinary scene of members of the Labor Party National Executive, CFMEU members, urging their members to vote for the Liberal Party. That was a snapshot which encapsulated the overall theme of the election-that is, every day you considering on an intervention. I do not think he was not advocating a vote for Mark Latham. Certainly the timber workers were very happy to see the Prime Minister. I think if you look at the result in Braddon and in Bass you can see that that was strongly reflected. It does take a lot of discipline and experience to run our economy. Every day there are decisions to be made. Let us look at the key challenges we face. First of all, there is the ageing of our economy. speaker: Dr Southcott
theText: PerhapsI should clarify this. A member of the Labor Party Nationalwill double. This has important implications in terms of increases in what we will be paying in health costs for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and so on. Having said that, I believe Australia is in very good shape to meet this challenge because of our strong retirement income system with a means-tested pension and compulsory superannuation. What this means is that our estimates are that we should only be paying about an extra two per cent of GDP over the next 40 years for the age pension. Compare this to some other countries like Canada, for example, where it is expected that they will be spending about six per cent of GDP on the age pension. The OECD average is about three per cent extra of GDP. I believe that we are well placed to meet the challenges and opportunities. But in only 15 years time, in the decade beginning the 2020s, we expect to see growth in the work force slow. Where we would normally expect 180,000 new workers to enter the work force every year, because that has been the pattern, in the whole decade of the 2020s the work force will grow by only 120,000, and by the time we get to the decade of the 2040s our work force growth will be only 0.1 per cent. So we will not see the increases in the work force that we have always had. But in countries with much lower fertility rates and where ageing is more advanced, such as in southern Europe, Spain, Italy, Greece, Japan, South Korea and so on, the populations will be ageing much faster. They will actually see periods of work force decline. It is not expected that we will see this in Australia. But it is important that we address the reasons why we have a very low work force participation rate amongst people aged from 45 to 64 years. We need to make sure that we take advantage of all the human capital in our society and that people are able to get the personal rewards available by working. In terms of the approach that the government has taken, which is exemplified in this budget, what are the challenges we face? First of all, we need to increase work force participation rates, especially among the group aged from 45 to 64 years. The Prime Minister is to be commended for appointing a specific Minister for Workforce Participation, the member for Dickson, whom I am delighted to see in that position. We also need further reform of the economy, including tax reform and making sure that infrastructure is in place so that we do not have any bottlenecks in the economy and including workplace relations reform, because it is very important to have wages set at the enterprise level, not by a centralised tribunal. Lastly, I want to touch on families. When the Howard government were elected in 1996, one of the things we did through family tax benefit part A and part B was to see that the relative position of lowand middle-income families was improved vis-a-vis the rest. For example, the family payment, which was only about $600 in 1996, is now about $1,800. We did that because we recognise the importance of families in our community, and the figures in the budget documents do show how the real incomes of dual-income families and single-income families have increased over the last 10 years. On the skills side, skill shortages are emerging, as I have said, and there is funding in this budget to improve vocational education and training through our new Australian technical colleges. But I am also very pleased to see that we have increased our skilled migration by 20,000. Lastly, on local issues, one of the key local things I pushed for in this budget was federal contribution to the South-West Indoor Aquatic Centre. I believe the Marion council did put in a very good submission. It was supported by all of the peak aquatic sport and swimming MAIN COMMITTEE groups. We had a very good reception from the Minister for the Arts and Sport, Senator Rod Kemp, and the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Nick Minchin. I am disappointed that we were not able to get funding this year, but it is worth remembering that, for example, Mount Panorama, which I believe received $10 million in the 2001 budget, only got that at their fourth attempt and only after a very concrete contribution from the NSW state government. Having said that, it is important to note that swimming pools and aquatic centres are not normally core business of federal government, except where there is a specific case. As I have said in a previous speech, we have no FINA standard pool in South Australia. We do need one. Our local swimmers, our junior swimmers, can never compete in national championships in their own state. We cannot host a national championship because we have no FINA standard pool. infrastructure Australia desperately needs and, tragically, is therefore another wasted opportunity by the Howard government. The budget fails to adequately invest in the health care, child care and aged care so urgently needed in Sydney’s inner west and instead spends $21.7 billion on an unfair tax cut, providing little incentive for lower income earners, and insults 80 per cent of honest taxpayers in my electorate of Lowe by offering them a miserable tax cut of $6 a week. The government’s tax cuts are unfair. TodayI speak for the eight out of 10 taxpayers on average incomes in my electorate of Lowe who will see the lousy $6 a week. This is more evidence that once again the Howard government has sold short households and families in Sydney’s inner west. The tax cuts proposed by the government will cost more than $21 billion and are skewed heavily towards the highest income earners, with the maximum tax cut of $65 a week available only to those with a taxable income of $125,000 or more-that is, 280,000 taxpayers. The maximum tax cut available to those earning up to $63,000-that is, 7.4 million taxpayers and 80 per cent of constituents in my electorate-is just $6 a week. Under the government’s proposed package 45 per cent of the value of the tax cuts go to the top 10 per cent of taxpayers, while the remaining 90 per cent of taxpayers share the other 55 per cent of cuts. While an average-income earner in Sydney’s inner west will get a tax cut of $6 a week, a person earning $125,000 a year will gain an additional tax cut of $65 a week. I know this sort of tax reform must reflect the progressive nature of our income tax system, but this imbalance is unnecessary and therefore a lost opportunity to begin to adequately address other critical issues such as Australia’s skill shortage and urgent infrastructure needs. Worse, the government’s tax changes not only provide an unfair distributional outcome but also fail to adequately address the high effect of marginal tax rates for low-income earners moving from welfare to work. Many lower and middle-income earners face marginal tax rates of more than 60c in the dollar from income tax and the withdrawal of government benefits as they earn more private income. The opposition’s plan for fairer tax cuts would deliver a $12 a week tax cut to seven million Australians, providing fairer tax relief for 80 per cent of taxpayers in my electorate of Lowe, and could be delivered at the same cost. The plan announced by Mr Kim Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, delivers a $12 a week tax cut for those earning from $25,000 to $75,000, which is double what the government is providing. It will also preserve the government’s tax cut for people earning from $70,000 to $105,000. MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (10.21 Am)
theText: This budget fails to adequately invest in training andApplying from 1 January 2006, the government should cut the tax of people moving from welfare to work by introducing a welfare-to-work tax bonus. It should replace the existing low-income tax offset and, when fully implemented, fully offset any tax on the first $10,000 taxable income for people earning up to $20,000 a year. To improve incentives for lowincome earners, to help them in a meaningful way, the government should also extend the income range where the 17 per cent marginal tax rate applies by raising the threshold where the 30 per cent rate applies from $21,600 to $26,400. In addition, the government should also adopt Labor’s tax plan and deliver a tax cut of $12 a week for lowand middle-income earners. From1 July 2006, the government should extend the income range where the 30 per cent marginal tax rate applies by raising the threshold where the 42c rate applies from $63,000 to $67,000. This would compensate middle and higher income earners for the effect of bracket creep and ensure that at least 80 per cent of taxpayers pay a marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar or less. Finally, the income range where the 42 per cent marginal tax rate applies should be extended by lifting the threshold where the 47 per cent rate begins from $80,000 to $100,000. This would improve the competitiveness of Australia’s tax system. Labor’s plan would ensure that a worker or single-income family on average weekly earnings will over the next four years gain $936 more than under the proposals contained in this bill. Further, a dualincome family on $85,000 will over the next four years gain $1,872 more under Labor’s plan. As far as income tax relief is concerned, only Labor is willing to offer a fair outcome for Australian households by providing greater incentives for work and greater tax relief for the people who need it the most. While the government remains narrowly focused on supporting and rewarding Australia’s highest income earners-after all, they are the Howard government’s natural constituency-it fails to give urgently needed attention to other serious problems that most Australians would expect any worthy Australian government to address. Firstly, it is shameful that the Howard government believes it can get away with skewing so-called tax reform in favour of Australia’s highest income earners while flogging those Australians who are most disadvantaged. In this respect I will refer to an opinion piece written by Mr Frank Quinlan, the Executive Director of Catholic Welfare Australia, which was published in last week’s Catholic Weekly. Mr Quinlan precedes his opinion piece titled ‘Budget “a lost opportunity” to help the disadvantaged’ with the following: ‘Part of what makes Australia a good and decent society is our willingness to tilt the playing field in favour of low and middle income families with dependent children. This has been a defining philosophic commitment of mine for the past 20 years, not least in the area of taxation reform.’ Mr Quinlan then began: These are the words of the Prime Minister, John Howard, during his Menzies Research Centre Address in Sydney last week. Given the tax changes contained in the budget it is very difficult to believe the Prime Minister and his government are serious about anything else other than tilting the playing field away from the lowand middle-income families. As Mr Quinlan rightly continued: Reflecting on the Budget, Catholic Welfare Australia is dismayed that rather than tilting the playing field in favour of low and middle-income earners, it seems many of them are being sent to the sidelines, off the playing field altogether. MAIN COMMITTEE This is absolutely correct and it underlines why Labor opposes these unfair tax changes. Mr Quinlan continued: In a Budget that delivers an annual tax cut of more than $2,000 to those earning more than $100,000 a year ... low-income earners (those among the 20 per cent of Australian households that earn less than $12,000) receive a tax break of only $1.54 per week (not enough to buy a hamburger or a milkshake). Families on low incomes and middle incomes will have twice that figure consumed by the shift in the Medicare Safety Net in any case. There is no doubt that the Howard government’s tax changes in this bill fail to provide an incentive for people working on low incomes or the income tax relief to those who need it the most. While lowand middle-income earners are being sidelined by the Howard government, the story is reversed for those on the highest incomes. As I said earlier, the opposition believes that all Australians deserve some tax relief. Our income tax system is progressive in nature so it is obvious that higher income earners will always share in tax changes designed to give tax relief. However, it is scandalous that the Howard government continues to allow some high-income earners to avoid paying tax altogether. I bring to the attention of the House an answer to my question on notice No. 3 in this parliament to the Treasurer. On 17 November 2004, I asked the Treasurer: What proportion of (a) barristers, and (b) solicitors failed to lodge an income tax return on time in each of the financial years ended 1992 through to 2002. Following my 3½-year campaign to protect honest taxpayers, the Treasurer’s answer, provided by the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, confirmed that 36 per cent of barristers failed to lodge a return in 2003, with similar failures recorded every year from 1999. The Howard government flogs honest taxpayers and insults them with a $6 a week tax cut at the same time as it fails to crack down on the more than one-third of barristers who have broken the law and failed to lodge a tax return. It is bad enough that far too many of the legal profession have used their knowledge to avoid paying their fair share of tax or even lodging a tax return. Further, and incredibly, we now know that over one-third of barristers in Australia have not bothered to complete an income tax return and the Howard government has been allowing this to happen since at least 1999. It is an absolute disgrace that many of these people, who have taken oaths to protect the public interest, still believe that tax is optional for them and it is an absolute disgrace that the Howard government has allowed them to get away with that. This is an insult to the vast majority of honest taxpayers, who suffer an enormous and unfair burden under the Howard government-the same taxpayers the government believes only deserve a $6 a week tax cut. I ask: what is the government doing to assist the New South Wales Bar Association and other professional bodies to expel those rogue members who refuse to do the right thing and who bring their profession into disrepute? What is the government doing to help them protect the name of honest professionals-in this case the 64 per cent of barristers who did lodge a tax return on time? I began by saying that, in failing to address the problems faced by all Australians, this budget is a wasted opportunity. Why does the government ignore the increasingly sad and unfair Australia it is helping to create? I want to refer to the sixth annual Manning Clark lecture, delivered on 20 March 2005 by respected social researcher Mr Hugh Mackay. My colleagues in the federal parliamentary Labor Party’s social policy committee and I were priviMAIN COMMITTEE leged to welcome Mr Mackay to a meeting of the committee last week here in parliament. Mr Mackay is rightly raising the alarm about the fact that we have been living through: ... the restructure of the Australian economy. This has resulted in a cultural shift in which we have gradually learnt to live with a widespread sense of job insecurity. We have witnessed a significant shift from full-time to part-time work, from permanent to casual employment and we have seen the problem of underemployment emerge as a more significant issue than the problem of absolute unemployment. We know this insecurity will only get worse under the Howard government’s unnecessary and unfair industrial relations agenda. Further, Mr Mackay points out: The redistribution of work has resulted in a redistribution of wealth. We have widened the gap between the rich and the poor. The average annual household income of the top 20 per cent of Australian households is about $180,000. The average annual household income of the bottom 20 per cent of households is about $12,000. We are also living with our highest ever levels of personal and household debt. Such shifts throw out a challenge to our traditional ideal of egalitarianism and raise serious questions about whether we are prepared to allow Australia to become a three class society, stratified by the dollar. Why is the Howard government ignoring this challenge? Because, in my view, it believes that it can get away with governing for the minority of Australians who believe a growing divide in Australia is acceptable and that it can scare enough other Australians into keeping it in office. I believe this will not last, but, equally, Australia cannot afford the government’s complacency. My constituents need a federal government that is willing to invest more in the services, training and infrastructure needed to ease the pressure on our communities and our household budgets. The budget contains no plans for infrastructure spending to address the growing crisis of traffic congestion in Sydney’s inner west and throughout Australia’s major cities. This is a problem that must be addressed across all levels of government. Instead we suffer a serious lack of leadership from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, who is also the Deputy Prime Minister. This is an abdication of responsibility that matches the government’s handling of other critical transport related issues such as aircraft noise and overdevelopment at Sydney airport, not to mention the security debacle in the cargo and baggage-handling areas at Sydney airport. I raised this issue on 11 May 2005 in my question No. 1320 to the Minister for Justice and Customs. In view of the reports in yesterday’s and today’s Australian, I will be very interested to see his reply. With all the money in its slush fund, I also ask: why is the government not ensuring that the long-term operating plan for Sydney airport is fairly implemented and why is it not honouring its promise to build a second airport for the people of Sydney? The government remains idle as Australia suffers the terrible environmental consequences of and reduced productivity caused by its failure to respond to Australia’s urgent transport infrastructure needs. Further, the government’s key election health platform-the Medicare safety net-has been cut by $499 million. This will increase current thresholds from $300 to $500 for concession card holders and family tax benefit A recipients and from $700 to $1,000 for all others. The current safety net level was a ‘rock solid, ironclad guarantee’ before the last election, but now the Howard government wants households to pay more when they need a doctor. The budget will cut $1.3 billion from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme by increasing the safety net thresholds for prescriptions. The government is also punishing elderly Australians and cancer patients by removing calcium tablets from the PBS. This is both horribly MAIN COMMITTEE short-sighted and counterproductive, in my view. It is an unfair attack on Australian households in an area-that is, health care-that will cause maximum anxiety. In addition, at a time of a national skills crisis the budget fails to make any significant new investments in the education and training sectors. The budget contains no general growth funding for additional TAFE places, despite about 40,000 Australians being turned away from TAFE last year. The budget contains no growth funding for additional HECS places, despite the fact that Australian businesses are crying out for highly skilled professionals like engineers and scientists. The Howard government has failed to adopt the opposition’s proposal for a $2,000 trade completion bonus for traditional apprentices who complete their training. Having fewer apprentices in Sydney’s inner west-including a drop of 23 per cent in my electorate of Lowe-training in trades like bricklaying, plumbing and carpentry is an outrage when local businesses urgently need qualified tradespeople. This skills crisis hits all households and businesses through higher interest rates, increased costs and delays to building and renovations. The Howard government has also badly let down families in my electorate of Lowe by failing to invest in adequate child care. The budget contains no new funding for long day care and nothing to ease the shortage of care for the under-fives. Many parents with young children will be unable to work to help pay the family mortgage and stay relevant in the labour market because of the huge shortage in long day care places. The queue for child-care places in my electorate of Lowe continues to grow, and the government is failing to create new places. It is typical in the inner west for child-care facilities to have something in the order of 200 parents waiting to get their children into child care. The government should be addressing that, in my view. The long waiting lists for outside school hours care will continue because the funds allocated for new places will not be available until 2008-09. This means that parents who want to work past 3 pm are still being prevented from doing so due to the shortage of places. The budget also neglects families looking after elderly parents and relatives because it ignores the ongoing skills shortage and the funding inequities in aged care. It fails to invest in training and retention measures for aged care nurses and personal carers. It does not address the systemic problem in the allocation of aged care places exacerbating the current waiting list problems. We know that there is a national shortage of 10,000 residential aged care beds and that there are over 17,000 phantom beds-that is, 17,000 beds that have been announced by the government but have never been opened. The budget also ignores the need for adequate funding for high-care residents and for capital development. By failing to adequately invest in, and in some areas cutting funding to, health, education and training, child care and aged care, the Howard government is contributing to the terrible anxiety of households in Sydney’s inner west. I do not believe the Treasurer is serious when he expects this anxiety to be alleviated by a lousy $6 a week tax cut. In the time. I have left I want to confirm my support for the second reading amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the member for Lilley, that the House condemns the government for a budget which: (1) delivers grossly unfair tax relief which favours the highest income earners at the expense of ordinary Australian families; MAIN COMMITTEE (2) ignores the crippling effect of punishingly high effective marginal tax rates on workforce participation; (3) imposes harsh conditions on the income of the most vulnerable members of the community; (4) fails to invest in skills and infrastructure disregarding repeated warnings from the RBA and OECD about skills shortages and infrastructure bottlenecks; (5) exposes Australians to the risk of higher interest rates as a result of capacity constraints and escalating economic imbalances; (6) predicts a significantly slowing rate of real GDP growth to below the Australian long-term average and considerably below world GDP growth; (7) confirms continuing unsustainable current account deficits into the future; (8) predicts a continuing increase in Australia’s foreign debt; (9) predicts import growth to exceed export growth; and (10) contains a proposed Future Fund which is focused on offsetting the superannuation liability of Commonwealth employees at the expense of sensible long-term investment in vital infrastructure”. I encourage the government to adopt our amendment and make this a fairer budget in the interests of the future of Australia. (Time expired) this very sound and responsible budget-the 10th budget delivered by the Treasurer, Peter Costello. When I hear the contributions of the members opposite in this House, I sometimes wonder whether we are in the same parliament or whether we have a literacy problem, as they do not seem to be able to read the legislation that has been announced. The previous speaker, the member for Lowe, was decrying the shortage of long day care centres in his electorate. I remind the member for Lowe that there is not a cap on long day care centres. If there is a shortage, make sure you go out and fight for your electorate rather than simply coming into the House and complaining. The measures and priorities in this budget are an investment in Australia’s future. It is a budget about aspiration. The budget also comes at a time that is right to make important structural changes to help ease people away from the growing trap of welfare dependency. In 1996, when we came into office, the focus was on dragging the economy out of the debt mire of the Keating era. Since then the government has delivered eight surplus budgets, which have helped to restore confidence in the Australian economy and, in turn, opportunities for Australians. I am proud to be part of a government that has introduced major initiatives throughout this term. On top of record investment into vital services such as health, education and aged care, this government has never lost sight of its genuine reformist zeal. There has been vital tax reform, important structural changes to the health system, and an emphasis on accountability and sustainability in the aged care sector. Furthermore, the workplace relations system has also had much needed reform. The new IR reforms, announced as recently as last Thursday by the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, are a welcome step and should lead to more jobs, better wages and improved conditions for Australian workers. These workers have received far better outcomes from this government than the 13 years of the previous government, where real wages only went up by about 1.3 to 1.4 per cent, compared to 14 per cent under this government. MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Barresi (Deakin) (10.41 Am)
theText: It is a pleasure to rise in this House and speak aboutNine years of pain-following Labor’s $96 billion debt-have helped put the economy in great shape. This is the eighth budget that has delivered a surplus. As the Treasurer said on budget night, before we came into office the Labor government was in deficit by two per cent of GDP. Two per cent of GDP in today’s terms is $19 billion-money which could have been better spent on vital services and programs in this country. We are paying off that debt. By June-July next year we will have reduced that net debt by $90 billion. We are paying off Labor’s debt and soon we will begin saving-saving for the future, and, as the Treasurer says, saving for the ageing of the population and for the opportunities of future generations. This is a record that every member of the government can be very proud of. The Australian public have certainly recognised this time and again by re-endorsing us as their government of choice. It is also important that we use this strong position to set the scene for the future. At present, we are well aware that Australia’s population is ageing. The time is right to make important changes to ensure that we remain on a sustainable footing. I am pleased that this budget is placing an important emphasis on moving people off welfare and into the work force. Our task now is to help people find a balanced approach where they can participate in the work force. It is important to help prevent people from feeling that they cannot afford to move back into work. It is important for them to once again start feeling good about themselves. They need to develop positive feelings about themselves and to develop self-esteem and a feeling that they can make a contribution to this nation. This is not a budget that is about punishment. It is a budget that provides support and assistance to those who are seeking to return to the work force. To illustrate the importance of participating in the work force, I turn to a study recently commissioned by the Australian Institute of Family Studies. This study highlighted a very important point. In their report Growing up in Australia, the institute found that 70 per cent of parents feel that working makes them more competent parents. The study focused on the families of 1,000 infants under 12 months old and children under 4 and 5. The results are very significant because they go a long way towards dispelling the misguided assertion that parents who want to return to work will harm their children’s development. In most cases, of course, the parents we are referring to are mothers who are seeking to return to work. This assertion is misguided, because it does not harm the children’s development. In fact, as the study shows, it assists the competency of those parents to deliver a meaningful, loving environment for their children. The positive effects of a steady job and a life outside of the home cannot be overestimated. I read with interest comments in the Melbourne Age by the director of the study, Ann Stanson of the University of Melbourne. In discussing the results of the survey, Ms Stanson stated: ... a lot of parents feel that outside involvement helps them to be positive and responsive to their children when they are there. It is important in the context of this debate to highlight that a healthy working life can be good for a parent. This is particularly pertinent for very young mothers who have children prior to entering the work force. I am sure we all know of such cases. If a young mother moves onto a parenting payment as her first source of permanent income, it can be even more difficult for her to move into and establish herself in a workplace environment. In many cases, young single mothers want to work. The workplace environment can provide purpose and an avenue for a young mother to make new friends and build selfMAIN COMMITTEE confidence, self-esteem and feelings of self-worth. The last thing that a young mother in her early to mid-20s wants to face is a financial burden when she enters part-time work. This budget is all about assisting that transition and providing real incentive to make the transition into the work force. As many members in the chamber will be aware, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation, which I chair, recently tabled a report in the House. That report on increasing participation in paid work inquired into how we can lift the participation rate in Australia. At present, Australia’s work force participation rate is at 63.8 per cent. This is one of the lowest levels in the Western world and is a real long-term concern for our economy. One worrying observation that our committee heard is that Australia will have approximately 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill them by the year 2030. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 10.50 am to 11.06 am ticipation rate is one of the lowest in the OECD. The reasons for the slow participation rate are varied. Some of the terms are fast becoming part of our contemporary vernacular. Terms such as ‘ageing population’ and ‘skills shortages’ are often thrown about; they certainly feature prominently in the current national debate. A significant recommendation from the report I was referring to is recommendation 4, which I would like to share with the chamber: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government review the tax free threshold, taper rates, effective marginal tax rates and income test stacking to maximise incentives to move from income support payments to increased participation in paid work. I am pleased to see the fast adoption in the budget of part of this recommendation. Lifting the allowable income level to $37,500 before family tax benefit A decreases will help ease single parents back into the work force. This is good news for those looking to return to work. It provides an additional incentive through the tax system to make the transition. In combination with a decrease in the marginal tax rate from 17 to 15 per cent, those seeking to return to part-time work will have their benefits scaled down at a much reduced rate. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 11.07 am to 11.21 am ents-who are, in the main, females choosing to return to work-is the additional 84,300 outside school hours child-care places. These child-care places will be welcomed by those who are returning to work. Often, the criticism that is levelled at the government is about where these women are going to be able to place their kids and what facilities are going to be available for them.
