speaker: Mr Barresi
theText: As I was saying prior to the divisions, one of the key priorities for futuresustainable. I have already mentioned the need to encourage more single parents on parenting payments to get back into the work force. The other significant welfare payment that currently does not carry an obligation to seek work of any significance is the disability support pension, the DSP. I am pleased to see that there were some changes made in this year’s budget to encourage those on DSP, from 1 July next year, to increase their participation in the work force. In January 2004 a representative of the Australian Council of Social Service explained this shift to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation, which I chair. I am pleased to see the former deputy chair of the parliamentary committee in the chamber today. According to ACOSS, the increase has been, in part, attributable to switching from other benefits. It is more appealing to be on DSP than the Newstart allowance. It is important that people with a disability are not simply typecast as being unable to work. Just as importantly, I have come across disabled people in my electorate and throughout Australia. Many of them have strongly implored me to be allowed to work if they are able to do so. This budget is a $2 billion investment into services over the next four years, to help people find work. Members on the other side have made the accusation that it is about cost cutting and getting people off DPS. What they have failed to acknowledge is that there is no net gain from the changes to DSP and welfare to work for at least the next eight years. Of course, there are many different kinds of disabilities and not everybody is physically capable of working the prescribed 15 to 29 hours per week. But many people with often debilitating disabilities, such as neurological conditions, do want to make a contribution to the work force. One such group I have become familiar with are MS sufferers. I am fortunate to have the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Victoria based in my electorate at the Nerve Centre in Blackburn. The honourable member for Calwell and I had an opportunity to visit the MS Society in the course of the committee’s inquiry. The MS Society is a fantastic organisation that strongly lobbies in the best interests of people with this chronic and often disabling, disease. The MS Society has also highlighted the need for a change of culture towards employees with the condition. Employers can be reluctant to keep employees with MS on their books for the long term. Among many factors, the MS society has stated: Employers are often uncomfortable with discussing workplace accommodation and accede from fear of allegations of discrimination rather than a desire to provide appropriate assistance in the workplace. This is a real problem for those with MS. There is a feeling that it is not matter of ‘CanI find a job if I have MS?’ but rather ‘CanI make keep my job if I have MS?’ because of the degenerative nature of the disease. I strongly value the MS Society’s contribution to this issue, and I am endeavouring to work with them on establishing a pilot employment program under the Employment Innovation Fund. This project will provide an avenue for employees with MS to work through training and workplace integration and I look forward to its implementation in due course. In addition, the society and I plan to co-host a forum in my electorate later in this year, which will focus on workplace participation for people with disabilities. We hope to involve many of the local groups in the employment sector, particularly those employers who have a strong commitment, a strong desire, to lend a hand up to those with disabilities to enable them to enter into the workplace. MAIN COMMITTEE In the limited time. I have available I would like to touch on a number of other subjects, particularly the budget’s strong commitment to vocational education and training. We all know that the unemployment rate is currently 5.1 per cent, yet it is still important for us to invest strongly in increasing our skills base. The best time to encourage people into the work force is a time of low unemployment when jobs are available. We also need to acknowledge that there is a skills shortage in key industry sectors in this country. Through its budget allocation, this government is giving priority to vocational education and training. It is important to recognise that a love affair with a job begins at a young age. School age people in Deakin will benefit from some of the 4½ thousand new prevocational places announced in the budget. The $20 million for this initiative will support the $26 million that will go towards 7,000 new school based apprenticeships. We are pushing for a greater focus on vocational training. There are many more significant issues that I could go into, such as the $537 million to extend youth allowance and other assistance to young apprentices. I am sure there will be plenty of opportunities in coming weeks to debate these issues. One of the problems with school based apprenticeships is having the training recognised by the relevant industry sector. I have certainly encouraged the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, Gary Hardgrave, to identify some of the impediments in the Victorian system. These impediments prevent the school based apprenticeships and traineeships from being recognised by prospective employers. There is a real concern that a number of industry awards make it incredibly difficult for such recognition to take place. While they recognise the formal curriculum side of an apprentice’s training, often they will not recognise the workplace experience that accompanies it. It is not uncommon for an apprentice to be asked to start all over again when they have finished their school based apprenticeship. The ‘Local Answers’ funding included in this budget is important for my electorate of Deakin and has been most welcome. It has been directed at helping community groups do their fantastic work in our local area. It is targeted towards helping young people remain active. I have had several young people write to me and call my office about the need for recreational facilities, particularly in the City of Maroondah in Ringwood. For years young skaters and rollerbladers have had to travel to nearby Croydon to use outdoor skating facilities. The Maroondah City Council has long envisaged building a similar facility in Staley Gardens right in the middle of Ringwood. I recall in the election campaign making a commitment to ensure that we will get federal funding as part of a three-way contribution to establishing a skate park for the young people of Ringwood. A $50,000 commitment by the federal government is one which I know has been most welcomed and I was pleased to see that it was included in this year’s budget. It is satisfying to know that this funding will make a large difference for local youth. Just last sitting week I was fortunate enough to have one of my local schools, the Antonio Park Primary School from Mitcham, visit Parliament House. When I invited the students to ask questions, rather than asking the usual: ‘How much money do you earn? How often do you fly to Canberra? Do you miss your family and friends? What kind of car do you drive?’ the first question was, ‘Are you going to get us a skate park?’ It showed that it really is an issue of great interest to those young people and I am very pleased to see that we are able to help deliver that election commitment. MAIN COMMITTEE Other groups within my electorate that have benefited from this budget include the Scouts. I am pleased to see that funding was also made available to help two Scouts groups in particular with some much needed refurbishments to their halls. These groups are the Seventh Ringwood group and the First Eight group in Blackburn, with $15,000 and $20,000 respectively. It is good news for them. I know that every member in this House values the work that the scouting organisation does in their communities, and in encouraging amongst young people a sense of the virtues of life skills, leadership and service. The people of Deakin are an intelligent, diverse and articulate group of people. They keep me on my toes. They do not allow dominant issues to pass by without letting me know their diverse feelings. From time to time, some of these issues straddle the traditional demarcation belonging within the local, state and federal realm. One such issue which I have raised in this House on numerous occasions is the Scoresby Freeway. I am pleased to see that the federal government has kept its $560 million offer on the table for a toll-free road. I will not say anything more than that. It is on the table. I know that while Steve Bracks took much delight in the hyped-up sod turning of the project it is clear that the state government’s backflip on its no-tolls promise has not been forgotten by people of Deakin. (Time expired) Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney) (11.51 am)-I would be really pleased if government members used this opportunity in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 to do what speakers in the appropriations debate are supposed to do: come in here and talk about the budget, in particular about the Welfare to Work measures that are contained in this federal budget. We have 86 coalition MPs. One after the other they troop in, tell the good news story and troop back out again. WhatI am really interested in is how they can justify to their constituents-in particular to the poorest constituents-the iniquitous tax cuts in this budget and the harsh Welfare to Work measures. I cannot understand why members opposite think that if someone is wealthy they need to be given more money as an incentive to work yet if someone is poor they need to have money taken from them as an incentive to work. I want coalition MPs to come in here and explain to us why it is that they think shifting people on to newstart allowance-which has a higher taper rate than the parenting payment or the disability support pension, so that people who will be on newstart will lose 60c in the dollar for every dollar that they earn instead of 40c, like they do now with the parenting payment and the disability support pension-is going to encourage people to move from welfare to work. How does making it more expensive for people to pick up some part-time work, making it less attractive for them to do that, encourage people to move from welfare to work? I want coalition MPs to come in here and explain to us how cutting access to the JET program, the Jobs, Education and Training program that provides child care for people who undertake training to move from welfare to work-a marvellous program that was first developed by a Labor government-encourages people to move from welfare to work. At the moment people are able to access JET child care for longer than a period of a year. They go on it for a year and then if their course is not finished they can go on it for another year. This budget says that if your course is longer than a year you have no access to JET child care training. How can it be that making it harder for people to undertake training-like hairdressing apprenticeships, learning to be a social worker or studying to be a nurse or a teacher-will help them move from welfare to work? It is a mystery to me, and I would love to hear coalition members of parliament explain it. MAIN COMMITTEE I believe that shifting people from the disability support pension and from the parenting payment on to newstart from 2006 is simply a cost-cutting measure. The member for Deakin said that it is actually not going to save money in the short term. The reason it is not saving money is not because of any of the Welfare to Work measures in it; it is because of the policing of those measures, because we are going to come down like a tonne of bricks on single mums who cannot find child care and thus cannot get part-time work. That is why it is expensive. We are going to pay the Job Network providers to breach people without explanation. The first time they do not turn up to a job interview, the Job Network provider will be able to get Centrelink to breach people, to rip them off benefits. That is where the expense comes in. It certainly does not come in from changing people to newstart allowance, which is going to be a major cost saver for this government. The second class of welfare recipients who are going to go on the parenting dole or the disabled dole are the hardest hit by this budget. I will talk a little bit about the tax cuts later on, but the people who should really concern us in this budget are the people who are going to be put on this second-class parenting dole and second-class disability dole. Disability support pensioners are going to lose $77 per fortnight. This is an enormous amount of money to someone who is on a benefit. It is not much to the Treasurer and his mates who are getting their $65 a week tax cut on top of their pay rise, but it is an enormous amount of money to someone who is on a disability support pension. It is not just because the cost of living is unaffordable to people who are on welfare benefits; people who are on disability support pensions have a number of additional costs. They often have lots of medication to pay for; they often spend a greater proportion of their money getting around just doing the ordinary things that people do from day to day. Some people have incontinence aids to pay for and all sorts of things that we do not consider to be day-to-day expenses. These are the necessary types of expenses for people on a disability support pension, and they cannot afford a $77 a fortnight cut. People who are sole parents will lose $44 a fortnight when they are moved onto the parenting dole. If they are working or getting money from a private source, they are going to be enormously hard-hit by this budget. In fact, some single parents who work part time will have their benefits slashed by up to $236 a fortnight. Under current arrangements, a single parent with four children under the age of 16 and who has $800 in private income gets $250.26 in parenting payment. From1 July that person will have their benefits cut by $236, and they will be left with a benefit of $13.80 a fortnight. How can we justify taking $236 from this sort of family? What the government seem to forget is, in their rush to punish these undeserving parents who are living the high life with their children, it is the children who suffer. It is always the children who suffer when money is taken from these sorts of vulnerable families. This family will be expected to suffer a 22½ per cent cut in their income. It is not just families in this scenario. Let us look at a single parent with one child between the age of six and 16. When they move onto the parenting dole, if they have $800 in private income a fortnight-if they are working a couple of days a week, maybe part time; they are doing exactly what it is that the government is asking single parents to do-they are going to lose $206.94 a fortnight. They would suffer a 20.3 per cent cut in their fortnightly income. Under the current regime, they would receive $220.74 a fortnight; under the new regime, they will receive just $13.80 a fortnight. How can we justify punishing parents who are doing exMAIN COMMITTEE actly what the government wishes them to do-working part time, improving their chances of full-time work as their children grow older-by taking from them $206.94 a fortnight? It just beggars belief. As well as this, there is also the second class of welfare recipients who sign up after 1 July 2006. They are not just going to lose $77 a fortnight if they are disability support pensioners or $44 or more a fortnight if they are sole parents; they are going to miss out on the higher rate of indexation of pensions, so the gap will grow over time. The gap that we are talking about now will only grow because of the different way that pensions are indexed from the newstart allowance. They are going to miss out on the pensioner education supplement. All of the rhetoric about the welfare to work measures has been about skilling people and sending them out into the work force. How can it be right then that we would take from such people the pensioner education supplement? How can that be right? What about the telephone allowance? Surely someone who is looking for work needs a telephone to be connected to the rest of the world. Surely this is a basic requirement of someone who is searching for work. But people on the new newstart allowance, the parenting dole or the disability dole will not get it. So any help that they were led to expect in moving from welfare to work will be undermined by that as well. The government has been trumpeting these welfare to work measures for months. People who watch these social issues were thinking: ‘Great! They must have something really great in their back pocket because they sure have been making a fuss about these welfare to work measures. It must be something pretty exciting.’ What a sad disappointment this budget has been. When it comes to moving people from welfare to work, it is all about punishment; it is all about stick and no reward, no carrot. It has been an enormous let-down. With $22 billion to spend on tax cuts, surely the government could have done a better job than giving 45 per cent of the tax cuts to the top 10 per cent of earners. I do not understand how it is that we have family tax benefit part B, which is essentially a reward to a primary carer of children for staying out of the work force. It is structured so that, in a family where there is a major breadwinner and someone on a much smaller income or no income, they are rewarded for staying out of the work force or for working a minimum number of hours. Other people have called it social engineering and said that it is an attempt by the government to keep women out of the work force. Yet, if a woman is a sole parent-if her husband has died or left her or if she has left him because he was bashing her and the kidsthen it is not a good thing for her to stay home with the kids. In those circumstances, when she is doing the job of raising her children on her own, suddenly she is a bludger. I cannot understand how we reward one set of parents for staying home and punish another set of parents for staying home, when the only difference between these two sets of parents is that in one instance they are in a couple and in the other they are on their own and doing it much tougher. The other thing we need to talk about when it comes to moving people from welfare to work is: where are these part-time jobs going to come from? The government has been very enthusiastic about the 83,400 out of school hours care places. That is terrific, and Labor welcomes any increase in out of school hours care places because there is a shortage around the country. On budget day in the lockup Treasury officials confirmed that there are already 35,000 children waiting for out of school hours care places. That is almost half gone. There is MAIN COMMITTEE no guarantee that any of these extra out of school hours care places will go to parents seeking to move from welfare to work. There is no tying of the extra places to parents who are seeking to move into the work force, and so it would be quite natural that a number of these places, perhaps the majority of them, would go to parents already in the work force. It is a real disappointment that this government has not done more in the area of out of school hours care and, more critically, in the area of long day care. One of the reasons that women get locked out of the work force and lose their skills is because it is impossible to find child care for children under the age of five and particularly for children under the age of two. When you do find it, it is so expensive that, unless you are a very high income earner, in many circumstances it is not worth your while going to work. So you take people who perhaps have a trade, a skill or a profession and you say to them: ‘For the next five years, it is not going to be economical for you to be in the work force. But when your child turns six, just like that, we expect you to pick up where you left off.’ That is not a reasonable thing to expect of people. If we had seen some more long day care places in this budget so that working women in particular could maintain their skills and maintain their attachment to the work force, which is so critical to people getting work, then perhaps I would be more convinced of the government’s sincerity. But the fact that there is nothing in this budget for long day care and that there is so very little when it comes to family day care really makes me question what it is that the government intends with its child-care announcement. I think basically it is window-dressing. It is supposed to make this budget look a little more compassionate than it is. It is worth remembering too that most single mothers are already working or looking for work-over 64 per cent of them. Most want to be in the work force. If we do something about child care and about training, I think there is a good chance that a lot of them will voluntarily move into the work force. At the moment all we seem to do is put hurdles in front of these people. All we seem to do is make it harder for them. As I said earlier, the harder we make it for the parents the harder it is on the kids. A lot of these kids are already skipping meals and missing out on school excursions, and the government’s solution is to move their parents onto a lower welfare benefit. If you look at this budget you also see that we are developing a two-tiered welfare system, which I think is appalling. I think that it is shocking that we are moving to a system where, if you are on a benefit on a certain day, you get one rate but, if you are in the same circumstances and have the same need for government support but you go onto the benefit after 1 July 2006, you will get a different amount. That is incomprehensible. I was interested to see that Ross Gittins also found it incomprehensible. In his column last week he said that this decision is: ... a cold-blooded decision to switch the nation to a two-class welfare system-a system where some people get benefits a lot higher than others. He points to people on the age benefit who will retain their higher benefits and their higher taper rate and he compares them with the people who are going to go onto the parenting dole and the disability dole. He says: The lower class will be the unemployed, sole parents whose youngest is six or older and people with disabilities who are judged capable more than 15 but less than 29 hours a week. They will get a benefit indexed the consumer price indexMAIN COMMITTEE in contrast to the pension, which is indexed to male total average weekly earnings. Ross Gittins says the reason the government have been boasting about how their package is going to cost a bit is that they have been trying to portray that as an indication that they are in fact doing something constructive to move people from welfare to work. He points out that it costs a fair bit just to impose the work test-hassling people about how many jobs they have been applying for-on people who formerly would not have been subject to it. But the government has admitted that the package of changes will be saving the budget money after about eight years. We know why it will be saving people money: because people are going to be on a lower benefit with a higher taper rate, and they are going to miss out on programs like the JET program and the pensioner education supplement and the telephone allowance and all the other benefits they will miss out on. Ross Gittins concludes by saying: The real saving will come simply from screwing working-age welfare recipients a lot harder than the politically untouchable golden oldies. I think Ross Gittins hit the nail on the head. The other thing that is important to remember when it comes to what is keeping people out of the work force is child care, which I already mentioned. Child care has had what is called a broadband review. The minister has been looking at all the different types of child care and what we are going to do with all of them. The bad news is that some services are going to miss out. One that is going to miss out is in Daylesford Victoria. On 23 May 2005 David Wroe wrote in the Age: The irony of this month’s federal budget was not lost on single mother Michelle Lowndes. As the Government encourages single parents into work, it is tinkering with a child-care funding formula that might force the Daylesford Community Child Care Centre to close, in turn forcing Ms Lowndes to quit her part-time work and studies. The manager of the centre, Julie McLean, is quoted as saying: What seems to be missing from the equation is that the low-income people in this area cannot afford to be paying higher fees. The member for Ballarat, Catherine King, presented to the parliament a petition with 700 signatures about the closure of Daylesford Child Care Centre. Because of this government’s policies, centres like the one at Daylesford, which help working parents to balance their work and family responsibilities, will close. I do not think this is irony. It was described in the newspaper as irony, but it is hypocrisy. To say, on the one hand, ‘We are going to help people get from welfare to work,’ and, on the other hand, to take away from them every support that helps them move from welfare to work-their child care, their training opportunities-is not irony; it is hypocrisy. The range of training and support measures provided in the budget is manifestly inadequate. Recipients of the disability support pension currently number 700,000 and recipients of the parenting payment 600,000. As well, there are about 65,000 mature age recipients of newstart. So there is a group of 1.3 million people that we are hoping to move from welfare to work. What have we done for these people? We have allocated 136,600 additional Job Network places. Someone is going to miss out. Only one in 10 people will get access to an additional Job Network place. There are 7,600 vocational training places for 700,000 disability MAIN COMMITTEE support pension recipients. Training measures provided in the budget are manifestly inadequate. The problem is that a significant number-about 60 per cent-of the target group have only a year 10 or equivalent qualification. Something serious needs to be done about their training and their child-care needs. This is not about moving them from welfare to work. It is about cutting their benefits. This is a great budget for Australia, and it is a great budget for the people of Ryan, whom I have the great privilege of representing in this parliament. The people of Ryan are very supportive of the government. That was reflected in my overwhelming re-election only several months ago, in October last year, which resulted in a substantial increase in my vote. I am delighted to say to the people of Ryan that it is great honour to be their local representative in the Australian parliament. I call on the Labor opposition to pass the government’s budget so that Australia, including the people of Ryan, can benefit from the budget measures. This is important for the people of Ryan and it is important for the businesses of Ryan. It is absolutely undesirable that the government, which was re-elected in October last year, cannot have its measures passed immediately. So, stop the obstruction, stop the senseless politics and stop the blatant opportunism. It is important that a government with a very strong mandate can implement its policies. This will certainly be seen post 1 July, when the new Senate takes its form. The government’s measures can then be implemented fully and extensively. However one looks at this budget, whether it is income tax cuts, small business, welfare to work measures, health care funding, our international engagement or providing for the future of Australians through the future fund, this budget caters for all sectors of the economy and makes a very strong contribution to Australian society, in all its forms. I want to take the opportunity to refer the parliament to the days of the Keating government and make a comparison between how the economy stood at that time and how the economy stands under the very strong leadership of Prime Minister Howard and his cabinet. In 1996, the Keating government’s budget deficit was $96 billion-two per cent of the nation’s GDP. Interest payments alone were some $9 billion. The inflation rate was over five per cent. A million people were out of work, and the unemployment rate was going through the roof. I am sure that many people in my electorate were affected by those figures. Mortgage interest rates were astoundingly high, at 18 to 20 per cent. Business confidence was at an all-time low, and small businesses were paying through the roof-with interest rates of over 20 per cent. The taxation system and the industrial relations system were shambolic and outdated. This begs the question: who was the finance minister at that time? It was none other than the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, the member for Brand. The people in my electorate of Ryan have spoken decisively, having returned a Liberal member to this parliament and having played a strong part in returning the Howard government on three successive occasions for four election wins. The coalition election victory in 1996, after a decade of Labor neglect, was very significant for this country. I am sure that when the Prime Minister took office he surveyed the scene and saw that the challenges facing him as the new Prime Minister of this country were very significant. There were always going to be massive challenges. Of course the government went to work straight away and took to the 1998 election a very historic taxation reform package. It MAIN COMMITTEE

theText: I am very pleased to speak in the debate on the Apasked the people of Australia for a mandate to implement those reforms, and those reforms have taken this country into the 21st century and set us up for decades of prosperity and growth if we can continue to govern wisely. Those reforms are going to set up this country so that my children and grandchildren, and the children and grandchildren of every member of this parliament, will prosper. Not surprisingly, the ALP opposition stood in the way of these tax reforms of the 1998 election-the so-called GST election. I am sure the opposition thought they could surf to victory by being a small target. The Australian people showed very strongly that they were not going to be taken for a ride and saw straight through the blatant opportunism of the small target campaign that was adopted. We do not hear too much about it now, but their policy was one of roll-back-that is, rolling back the GST reforms. word was roll-back. I am not sure when that word was last mentioned in the House of Representatives or indeed in the Senate-I might check on that in Hansard and advise my colleague. I am sure his electorate would be very keen to hear about this as well. I know that he is doing a fine job representing his constituents. The roll-back policy is dead and buried. It proved to be something on which the Australian people were not going to be taken for a ride. Thankfully for that, Australia today is a much better place. We are enjoying remarkable economic growth and remarkable prosperity-something which has allowed the government to deliver vital services to take this country forward. On budget night the Treasurer delivered his eighth successive budget surplus. The federal government’s cash budget surplus stands at $8.9 billion. This represents a surplus of one per cent of GDP. The unemployment level is at an almost 30-year low of 5.1 per cent. Isn’t that remarkable? I would like to refer to the remarks of the previous speaker, the member for Sydney, about welfare to work. She seemed to focus a lot on that. The best thing you can do for people in this country is to give them a job. The best thing we can do is to give them a highly paid job, and this government focuses very much on skills and training. That is what is going to take people off welfare and into the employment market. Over the past nine years, real wages have risen in this country by 14 per cent, which compares most favourably to the 1.2 per cent rise over the 13 years of the ALP government. As the Prime Minister said recently, we are now in the 14th year of the longest unbroken economic expansion that Australia has had at any time since World War II. That is a very significant statement of fact. I remind the parliament that the ALP left office in 1996 with a $96 billion budget deficit, or two per cent of GDP. Why is this important to the people of Ryan? It is very important because what that meant was that we were paying an incredible amount of interest. What did that do? It deprived the people of Ryan and the rest of the country of vital amounts of money for services to hospitals, the education sector and other important areas of the economy. Labor’s debt has been repaid to the tune of $90 billion. It has certainly been hard going, but we are making those repayments in the interests of our children, our grandchildren and the future of this country. Only by reducing the principal of that debt can we remove further interest payments. By doing that, $5.7 billion of interest payments have been freed up. We are talking about a very significant amount of money. MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Johnson
theText: I am happy to advise my National Party coalition colleague that thatPeople have asked me from time to time in the Ryan electorate, ‘Why do you keep harping on about this budget deficit that the Labor government left you in 1996?’ I say to them, and I again say today in the parliament, that I go on about it because it is very important to remind the Australian community that when Labor were in government they did not have the capacity to run the economy in the interests of the Australian community. How can you run a country with a massive debt and not expect that to catch up with the country some time down the track? For the people of Ryan, and their children and grandchildren, the government’s policies will make their lives and their economic prosperity much better into the future. We are certainly the envy of other nations. I want to take the opportunity, while I am speaking on the debt that Labor had when they were in office, to remind the parliament, and-as the re-elected member for Ryan-to remind the people of Ryan, of the debt figures during the Hawke-Keating years. In 1991 there was a Commonwealth net debt of $31 billion. In 1992 it was $55 billion. In 1993 it was $70 billion. In 1994 it was $83 billion. In 1995 it was $95 billion. And of course in 1996 the Howard government confronted over $96 billion of government debt. I think it was very significant that the Howard government was elected to redress that economic crisis confronting the country. In 1997, the first year after the Howard government was elected, the debt was $82 billion. It came down in 1998 to $70 billion. In 1999 it was $57 billion. In 2000 it was $42 billion. It continued to go down. In 2001 it was $38 billion. In 2002, $32 billion was owed. This government has made the tough calls, the tough decisions that only a government can make. Being in opposition it is very easy to have a go at the government, but the decisions do not lie with oppositions; they lie with governments. For the people of Ryan this is very significant indeed. I want to remind the people of Ryan, and indeed the broader Brisbane and Queensland electorates, that Queensland as a state benefits from GST revenues to the tune of $35 billion. Hopefully the state government will get on with abolishing the whole basket of indirect taxes that Queenslanders have been slugged with. I want to call on the Queensland government, while they continue to receive this windfall of cash, to spend some of that money on the roads in my Ryan electorate. Spend some money on Moggill Road. So far it is all talk and no action. I know the people of Ryan are getting sick and tired of the Queensland government reaping in all this money from the GST, which as a Labor government they opposed-although they were the first in fact to sign the document. Now they are receiving all this money and I call on them to spend some money on local infrastructure. Moggill Road is a state road. The Labor government has been in power in Queensland since 1989, bar two years of the Borbidge government. Now it is 2005 and Moggill Road remains in the same condition as in 1989. This is something that I think will be very instructive to follow in the months ahead. I turn my attention now to the tax cut measures introduced in the budget by the Treasurer. The government’s tax cuts are due to be delivered on 1 July, and I hope that they will be, because the people of Ryan certainly deserve their income tax cuts. There will be almost $22 billion worth of income tax cuts in the country. I think the small businesses and the families and the people of my electorate of Ryan are looking forward very much to them, because they deserve them. They deserve them because they have been working hard. They are the ones who loyally pay their taxes, who make a contribution to this community, to this country. With the economy growing very strongly and the country being run tremendously well, it is entirely MAIN COMMITTEE appropriate that they receive their tax cuts as soon as possible-not next year, not the year after and not in the next parliament, as the Labor opposition have called for. What was the Labor opposition’s response to the government’s tax cuts? It was not to support them. The budget has been delivered in 2005 and how have they responded? They have proposed tax cuts in the next parliament-not in the 42nd Parliament but in the 43rd Parliament. That is absolutely astonishing. What are these tax cuts going to do? They are going to boost disposable income. They are going to, as I say, reward the hard working people of Australia. More than anything, they are going to assist low-income earners. I cannot believe that a party that is the so-called friend of the workers will not pass budgetary measures that support low-income earners. That is absolutely astonishing. What the new tax scales mean is that over 80 per cent of Australian taxpayers will face a top marginal income tax rate of 30 per cent or less. Ms HallMr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene. way? face a top marginal rate of 47c in the dollar. The top tax rate of 47 per cent will now come in at $95,000, and increase to $125,000 in July 2006. Let me make a comparison with some of the other countries in the world. The US is 43 per cent and it cuts in at $425,000. Japan’s top rate of 46 per cent applies at $A275,000. In the UK it is 41 per cent, at $87,000. The top tax rate in New Zealand is 39 per cent and cuts in at $55,000, and in Canada it is $120,000. This is a major step forward for the Australian taxpayer. However, it is by no means sufficient. I call for further income tax cuts for the people of Ryan and the Australian community. The tax measures that were passed are by no means tax cuts only for the rich, as the Labor Party so spuriously claims. The Labor Party does not even want to pass tax cut measures that will help lower income earners. I can certainly say to the Labor Party that the low-income earners of Ryan will not be sending it any bouquets, that is for sure. These tax cuts are very consistent with an economy that is growing. They are very consistent with the responsible financial stewardship of the nation. But what was the ALP’s response? In the House of Representatives, they voted against the cuts, of course-not only for those on higher incomes but also for those on lower incomes. The Labor Party are supposedly a party that supports lower income earners and only the workers, but they do not want to give them those tax cuts. I think the sheer hypocrisy of the Labor opposition will come home to roost. I think it is very important for the Australian community to know that the myth that the ALP are the workers’ best friend is just that: a myth. The Australian people will see straight through it. Fewer than one in five Australians are members of trade unions. In fact, I think only 17 per cent of the work force is in a union-less than one-fifth of the work force. In the first decade of the 21st century we continue to hear the ALP go on about how it is the party of the worker, but I think those days are gone. They are finished; they are dead and buried. There are more coalition members representing constituents with lower incomes than there are in the ALP. Of course we do have many more members. speaker: Mr Johnson
theText: I will continue with my speech. Only three per cent of Australians willrespect and the regard of their constituents. In the House of Representatives I think this will show very strongly yet again when the next election is held. The Australian people-and certainly I speak for the people of the Ryan electorate-are only interested in outcomes. They are not interested in outdated, 19th century ideological mindsets. They want outcomes, and our government are delivering them. When was the ALP going to offer its version of tax cuts? In 2008-not even in the life of this parliament. That is absolutely remarkable. We are talking about a budget that was delivered in 2005, a budget that offers tax cuts to the broad spectrum of the Australian community. How does it work that the Labor opposition’s budget reply in 2005 offers tax cuts not in the same year but in a separate parliamentary term? It would be an absolute laughing matter if it were not for the fact that we are talking about policy initiatives from the leader of a major political party, from a man who wants to be Prime Minister of this country, from a man who sets himself up as the alternative Prime Minister. It would be a laughing matter but for the fact that it is so serious an issue. I want to turn my attention to small business, because small business in Ryan is very important to me, to the broader communities in the suburbs of Ryan, to the families of Ryan and of course to those who own and operate small businesses. As I have said, Labor’s tax response proposed to pass its tax cuts not this year but in 2008. Worse than that, Labor are also denying small businesses and small business owners in Ryan the opportunity of receiving the government’s tax cuts. There are some 1.3 million small businesses in Australia, and they are a key to Australia’s strong economic growth. By assisting them to grow, we are going to provide more jobs to the Australian community. The Howard government has been very conscious of the importance of small business in this country, and certainly I am very conscious of that in the Ryan electorate. One of the important measures of this year’s budget was to abolish the three per cent tariff on imported business inputs, a measure which I think adds in excess of $1.3 billion of savings for small business over the next five years. A broad range of business expenses will also be tax deductible and will foster small business growth and profitability. I also want to alert the Ryan electorate to improved access to the simplified tax system. It will provide tax relief to small businesses and is worth some $360 million. As I said, income tax cuts are very significant both at a personal level and also at a business level. I want to conclude by saying that it is very important that the budget measures introduced by the Treasurer in the parliament get passed by this parliament. I want to call on the opposition to pass them very soon. This is a family-friendly budget, a worker-friendly budget, a business-friendly budget, an Australia-friendly budget and a Ryan-friendly budget. The Australian people and the people of Ryan continue to support the Howard government in office because they know that it takes a very strong government to make the strong decisions that will benefit the Australian community, that will benefit the businesses of this country and that will benefit individuals. They took the tough decisions in the 1996 election and in the 1998 election, with the GST reforms and the industrial relations reforms that are about to come through the parliament. I think the Australian people will see through the blatant opportunism that the Labor Party continue to talk about in this parliament. Instead of offering policies, instead of coming up with ideas, instead of coming up with initiatives that will actually improve the lifestyle of Australians, they are only on about blatant politics. (Time expired) MAIN COMMITTEE Ms CORCORAN (Isaacs) (12.31 pm)-The Howard government has failed our society, even by its own liberal values. One of the deepest insights of the classical liberal tradition is that each member of our society is valuable and has potential. I can only paint word pictures for you, but I challenge members of the government to go into the Centrelink offices, the welfare agencies, the homeless centres and the women’s refuges and see for themselves the despair, the frustration and the suffering that some people are going through. Stop your busyness and feel the poverty that is happening right here in this country, a country that should be so good to live in. There is an underclass of poverty-stricken people. There is an underclass suffering from despair. It is growing and has been growing like a noxious weed under this government. The people being ignored or being battered by this government include the unemployed, the underemployed, sole parents, those suffering a disability and people caring for others unable to care for themselves. This government goes from one vulnerable group to the next, stigmatising, denouncing and threatening them. It has been put to me that the government’s actions suggest that it sees these groups of people as valueless and without potential. That person then offered me another thought-that the government deliberately sets up disadvantaged people as a class against which the government defines itself. It has become clear to me over recent years that the government has deliberately tried, and to some extent has succeeded, in setting Australians against Australians, and it is this trend that my constituent is talking about. Today in Australia, on Howard’s watch, it is becoming okay to denigrate those on social security payments, it is becoming okay to denigrate those who come from overseas seeking our protection and help, and it is becoming okay to denigrate those who hold different religious beliefs or even none at all. It is becoming okay to stop caring about our neighbours, both local and global, and just narrow our focus to ourselves. A classic proof of this came the day after the Treasurer’s budget speech. The Daily Telegraph’s headline read ‘Workers 1, shirkers 0: The tax system finally rewards effort and makes the bludgers pay’. The article goes on to talk about workers winning and shirkers feeling the heat. The implication is that anyone on a social security payment is a shirker. This is provocative language and a clear example of whistleblowing-that is, it appeals to those who are already predisposed to think ill of people on welfare and just want an excuse to do so. It encourages the notion that the world is a simple place and consists of people who work hard and those who prefer to lean on others. In this black-and-white world there are no people who have accidents, or, if they do, they have the wherewithal to look after themselves, they recover completely and they return to work without any further problems. In this black-and-white world all marriages or relationships last happily forever or, if they do not, the partners have the grace to continue to live together quietly, providing good care for their kids and not abusing each other. In this blackand-white world no decent people have an alcohol problem or an addiction to illicit or legal drugs. Those that do are seen, firstly, as having wantonly brought their problems on themselves and, secondly, as not worthy of any assistance beyond the recommendation that they pull up their socks and get on with it. These attitudes do not recognise that many people, through no fault of their own, require assistance from time to time and that some people require assistance on a long-term basis. These attitudes do not recognise that, regardless of why MAIN COMMITTEE some people are in need of help, there are often children involved and that we must, regardless of their parents’ actions, have concern for these children and provide adequately for them. This budget is a failure. It fails our society. It is not just and it is not fair. It does not treat the vulnerable as people with potential; rather, it attempts to separate them from others and treats them as a different species. It is my experience, listening to the distressed voices in my electorate, that disabled workers and single parents by and large want to participate in the work force. The trouble is that employers often do not want to employ them. The government’s own track record here is a classic example. The number of people with disabilities who are employed by this government is falling. The government makes a lot of noise about the recent increase in the number of people on disability pensions. The government is trying to suggest that there are a lot of people out there on a pension fraudulently. We hear disparaging comments about all those with bad backs, as though everyone with a bad back is pretending. It is reasonable-in fact, it is desirable-to ask why the numbers of disability pensioners are growing. It is then the government’s job to react properly to the cause, not simply to suggest that those on this support are shirkers or to make life more difficult for them. Those who are on a disability pension fraudulently should be identified and moved off. Those who are genuine should be treated with respect, provided with appropriate assistance to get a job that is consistent with their disability and provided with the assistance they need to live a decent life. Appropriate assistance includes recognising that some people cannot go to work every day, that sometimes they are well and capable and other times their illness means that they cannot work. Appropriate assistance means recognising that some people need assistance in the workplace-physical assistance or assistance that allows them to work at a different pace to others without fear of discrimination. Research suggests that there are several reasons why the numbers of those on disability pensions have increased. One reason is that the population is ageing and that older people are more likely to have disabilities. For example, men who have worked in a physical job all their lives often eventually sustain physical long-term injuries. A number of other social security pensions have been stopped. For instance, the age for which the pension is available to women is increasing to eventually reach 65 years of age. It is likely that in the past women aged between 60 and 65, unable to work because of a disability, went on to the aged pension. Many of these women are no longer able to do that because of the change in the age rules and so move on to the disability pension. Another reason cited by the research is that we are getting better at looking after people who sustain big injuries from accidents. More people are surviving and they need support through the disability support pension. These people should not be the subject of slurs by the government or by the community. They deserve appropriate support and respect. A constituent of mine has told me of the frustrations she is going through trying to get into the work force. Maree has been out of the work force for some time. She was her husband’s carer but they have now separated. Maree needs retraining and her confidence restored. She has had her name down for a place on the personal support program for many months and is despairing of ever getting onto this program. Maree spoke to me before this budget was brought down and said she was worried about having her single parent payments cut. She has one son. Her former husband is a pensioner, so there is not a lot of capacity for financial supMAIN COMMITTEE port from that source. Maree wants to get her drivers licence and to buy a car so that she can improve the range of jobs she can apply for. She cannot do this in the face of a threat of reducing income. If the mooted changes to the disability support pension and the parenting payments are made, those who are currently on these payments will be treated under one set of conditions while those who apply from 11 May for the DSP will be on another set of conditions and those who apply from 1 July 2006 will be on yet another set of conditions again. We are going to end up with groups of people who are operating under similar circumstances being treated very differently. This is going to be an administrative nightmare and, more to the point, it is very unfair to the recipients. The tax cuts proposed in this budget have been described as a welcome and overdue acknowledgment of the tax break hard working middle Australians deserve. I am not sure what middle Australia means in this context, but let us assume it means those on average incomes or in middle tax brackets. If the government was serious about rewarding hard working middle-income Australians, it could have designed a far better tax system than the one proposed. The proposed changes are: a reduction of two points in the 17 per cent marginal tax rate, down to 15 per cent; an increase in the threshold level for the 42 per cent margin rate-from $58,000 to $63,000 this year, with another move to $70,000 next year; and an increase in the highest marginal rate-from $70,000 to $95,000 this year and then on to $125,000 next year. This is on top of the tax break introduced last year for those on $50,000 a year or more. It is also on top of the complete abolition of the superannuation surcharge tax for those on high incomes, from this year. What all this means is that those on $50,000 per year or more had a tax cut last year, they will get one this year and they will get another one next year. Those on incomes below $50,000 will get one tax cut. The tax cuts are roughly as follows: there will be $18 per week for those on $20,000 or less; there will be $6 a week for those under $50,000; and those on $100,000 per year can look forward to $40 a week this year, moving to about $63 per week next year. That again is before we start considering the changes to the superannuation surcharge. Some people think it is okay for those earning more to get bigger tax breaks than those earning less. The argument usually runs along the following lines: those on higher incomes pay more tax in dollar terms in the first place, therefore of course they are going to get bigger tax cuts in dollar terms than those on smaller incomes. I have done an analysis of the proposed tax cuts to test this argument and I have come up with some interesting results. Firstly, as I noted earlier, those on higher incomes are getting a bigger tax cut in dollar terms than those on smaller incomes. Secondly, those on higher incomes are in many instances getting a bigger tax cut than those on smaller incomes in percentage terms as well. The tax cuts in percentage terms over the next two years, to 2006-07, are 13.1 per cent for those on an income of $20,000, six per cent for those on an income of $30,000, 3.8 per cent for those on an income of $40,000 and 2.8 per cent for those on an income of $50,000. So far, so good-the percentage tax cuts are moving in the direction you would expect and in the direction the government has said. However, from here on in the story changes. The tax cuts in percentage terms over the next two years, 2006-07, are 3.8 per cent for those on an income of $60,000, 9.4 per cent for those on an income of $70,000, 9.7 per cent for those on $80,000, 9.8 per cent for those on MAIN COMMITTEE $90,000, 9.9 per cent for those on $100,000 per year and 10.1 per cent for those with incomes of $120,000 per year. We have to move on to those on an income of $150,000 a year before the tax cuts in percentage terms start to fall again-down to eight per cent. I did not take my analysis any further than these income levels. Even so, it is a bit rich to say that someone on $150,000 can have a tax cut of eight per cent or $86 per week, while those on a third of that income, $50,000, get a tax cut of $6 per week or 2.8 per cent. Again, do not forget that the person on $150,000 also gets a tax cut, as the superannuation surcharge is abolished. The alternative plan put forward by Labor is much better. It proposes that from 1 January 2006 there should be a rise in the threshold where the 30c tax rate cuts in-from $21,600 to $26,400-and a welfare to work bonus that will provide an effective $10,000 tax-free threshold for people earning up to $20,000 per year. These would be followed by further tax cuts from 1 July 2006, which would raise the threshold where the 42c rate cuts in from $63,000 to $67,000 and would raise the threshold where the 47c rate cuts in from $80,000 to $100,000. These changes to the tax system will give a $12 per week tax cut for those earning from $25,000 to $70,000-double what the Liberal Party is proposing. They will give the same tax cuts as the government proposes to those earning from $70,000 up to $105,000. The changes will give a tax cut of $40 per week to those who earn $105,000, which is one-third less than the government is proposing and a much fairer outcome across the range. It is interesting to note that the Treasurer has not responded at all to this alternative proposal. He had the details of Labor’s tax policy for some hours before he was required to come back into the House and sum up the tax debate. He did not offer any comment or attempt to discuss the merits or otherwise of our policy. The government promised, in the lead-up to the 2001 election, that it would keep private health insurance affordable. It is a pity that it did not define ‘affordable’. Clearly, this promise is in the same ironclad, never-to-be-broken category as the Medicare safety net promise. I say this because private health insurance has increased by 33 per cent since 2001. This is hardly an affordable rise. This year, the government approved and announced an increase of 7.96 per cent in health insurance premiums. Many of my constituents, however, ended up with a rise of around 15 per cent. One gentleman who rang me was very upset. He joined private health insurance a few years ago. He was not sure he could afford it, but bowed to the pressure. The big push was on. But this latest rise is just too much for him and he is now going to get out. This means he will join many other Australians who are leaving private health insurance. The seniors health insurance rebate was meant to make the private health insurance industry more sustainable, but it is not working. The latest figures show that, so far this year, while 54,000 people over the age of 55 joined private health insurance, 21,000 people under the age of 55 got out. This leaves a lopsided private health insurance industry paying out record amounts in benefits, which is hardly a sustainable trend. Private health insurance is not affordable for many Australians and the latest move to prop up the industry is not working. Clearly there is a lot more work that needs to be done in this area. Child care, or at least the lack of child-care places, is a continuing theme with my constituents. This budget will do nothing to help them; in fact, it may make matters worse. This MAIN COMMITTEE budget does not attempt to match child-care places with need in either long day care or before and after school hours care. The government is intent on forcing parents out to work but has made no provision for the extra child care that this will demand. There is a total of 87,000 new before and after school hours care places in this budget, and this is welcomed. We know from ABS data-the office of the Minister for Family and Community Services does not keep this data-that there is an existing shortfall of around 174,500 places in Australia. We know, because the Treasurer has told us, that he wants 190,000 parents back in the work force. We do not know, however, how the extra child-care places needed to cope with 190,000 parents going back to work, plus the existing shortfall of 174,500 places, are going to be managed with the allocation of only 87,000 new places. Those figures are for before or after school hours care. There is nothing positive in this budget for long day care. There is a negative, however, which is very hard to understand. In the face of all the noise that the Treasurer is making about getting people back to work, he quietly cuts funding for child care to parents on low incomes whilst they undergo training or look for work. The JET scheme is now only available to parents who can do their training within 12 months. If you are interested in doing any training that takes more than 12 months, this scheme, which is aimed at low-income parents, is suddenly not available. Industry has, for some time now, been talking about a shortage of workers with the skills needed by industry. The Reserve Bank, last March, talked about this shortage too, as well as problems with our infrastructure. These two factors were the reasons given by the Reserve Bank to justify its decision to raise interest rates by 25 basis points at that time. The Reserve Bank was concerned that skills shortages would put pressure on wage costs and, therefore, inflation. Despite the fact that skills shortages have been talked about for years, this government has done nothing-worse, it has actually reduced capacity to improve the situation. Since 1998, over 270,000 Australians have been turned away from TAFE. We see that 40 per cent of our apprentices do not complete their apprenticeships. This is clearly unsustainable and needs to be addressed. Labor has announced a completion bonus to encourage apprentices to finish their training. This bonus would be in the form of $1,000 midway through the training, and another $1,000 once the training is complete. This money would be tax free. It is estimated that, should this policy be adopted, it would put another 8,000 trained apprentices into the market every year. We cannot afford to ignore the need for skilled workers. We must train up our own people, who are looking for training and ready to learn, rather than trying to rely on importing skilled migrants. In summary, this budget introduces a new tax schedule which is clearly unfair. It threatens the well-being of many households by moving parents off parenting payments and onto a lower social security payment. It threatens the well-being of many disabled people by threatening their incomes. It does nothing to address the training needs and child-care shortages which exist now and are becoming more acute. This budget is clearly a disgrace. appropriation bills. I am also proud to be a member of this government, delivering real outcomes for the people of Australia. One area that is of concern to me and that calls for greater attention by all governments is that of mental health. The provision of mental health services is one of the foundational issues of any well-governed nation. I am therefore glad to see in our 2005-06 budget that mental health remains one of this government’s health priorities. This MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mrs Vale (Hughes) (12.50 Pm)
theText: I am grateful to have the opportunity to speak on thebudget reaffirms the Howard government’s election commitment on mental health, with both the continuation of the better outcomes in mental health initiative, at cost of $102.2 million over four years from 2005-06, and new funding of $151.2 million over five years, from 200405, for three priority areas. The priority areas are $69 million for youth mental health, $39.6 million for the national depression initiative and $42.6 million for the expansion of the better outcomes in mental health program. The states have the constitutional responsibility for the provision of mental health services. AlthoughI understand that the Commonwealth takes the lead role in developing the National Mental Health Strategy, it does not provide any day-to-day direct services itself, but it does provide about 65 per cent of the total funds dedicated to mental health in Australia. This high proportion of funding suggests to me that the states are not pulling their weight in the provision of services to the mentally ill. In fact, while the Australian government has increased its contribution to mental health services by 73 per cent per capita, the increase by the states has only been 19.8 per cent. Regrettably, the worse offenders have been the largest states: New South Wales and Victoria. I understand that only about 10 per cent of the money that states have saved from the deinstitutionalisation over the last two decades, following the Richmond report, has been reinvested in services for the mentally ill. What a confidence trick this has been by the states and territories against Australian families: closing down residential care centres for the mentally ill, abandoning the sick to an unprepared community and then pocketing the money saved to curry political favour elsewhere. The whole rationale for closing down mental health institutions-indeed the promise-was to build community care to the point where the acute mentally ill would be better treated. Regrettably, the states have done nothing short of sabotaging government infrastructure and services for the mentally ill. But there is good news in this 2005 federal budget for improving mental health services and I welcome it. In so doing, I would like to address the issue often drawn to my attention by close family members of people with acute mental illness who, in their distress and anxiety, cry out for the provision of accessible and quality residential care for their loved ones. These caring Australians usually have a son or a daughter, a brother or a sister, who simply cannot look after themselves and who are beyond the sustainable care their families are able to give them. I would also point out that, sadly, there are some children-some under the age of 18who care for their barely functional mentally ill parents. These children are, in fact, the primary caregivers. In questioning the policy of deinstitutionalisation of care for the acute mentally ill, I may offend many mental health experts, but it is the people trapped at the coalface who I believe need to be heard. They never have had and still do not have any effective voice in the formation of mental health policy. In speaking to the legislation, I want to address a foundational policy upon which the National Mental Health Strategy has been constructed. I want to question the policy and the wisdom of experts that have focused only upon deinstitutionalised care for the acute mentally ill. I know that back in the fifties and the sixties in the area of institutionalised care there where human rights and other abuses in such institutions. There was a passive attitude towards rehabilitation programs, there was not nearly enough supervision and many people were just admitted to the institutions and, shamelessly, quickly forgotten. They were out of sight and out of mind. The situation then was a disgrace and there was an unquestioned need for reform. MAIN COMMITTEE Over the next two decades state governments of both sides of politics, acting on the advice of health professionals, principally through the Richmond and then the Burdekin reports, decided to close down residential care centres promising a bright new world of future community care. These were well intentioned policies. Sadly, the residential care centres were gradually closed but resources for community care have not lived up to their promise. The closure of residential care centres often forced people to go back to the inadequacies of the community. As a result, many found their way onto the streets and became almost permanently homeless. Many families had their lives disrupted by the closures as they struggled to adequately care for their acutely mentally ill loved ones. This had a domino effect, with many members of the caring family collapsing themselves in the attempt to support the relative they loved. Today they remain unrecorded statistics of suffering and a badly thought-through policy. The discovery of psychotropic drugs was a big help when turning people out of residential care, but even this wonderful medication still has serious and real limitations for many. Rarely does someone with a high profile who speaks out with authority, questioning the policy of deinstitutionalisation, come along. But this was the case when Professor Allan Fels, the former Chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, courageously spoke out about a member of his own family, his beloved daughter, who suffered from schizophrenia. I quote from the Sunday Herald Sun of 31 August 2003. In an article in the Medical Journal of Australia Professor Fels said: Moving those with the illnessthat is, schizophreniaout of the institutions and into the community had resulted in a reduced government-funded support structure and a greater burden on families. He said about his daughter: An attempt by Isobella to live away from home with others, in a house with mental health workers present from 9am to 5pm on weekdays, did not work. He goes on: She has under-developed living skill and her illness is such that she could not live by herself. She basically depends upon family care. A few days later, on 11 August in the Australian, Professor Fels was quoted as saying: We should be very wary of deinstitutionalisation in the light of the mental health experience, where there is inadequate resourcing of community care. For some people with a disability, a communal arrangement is better. There should be a choice rather than a single policy of deinstitutionalisation. Will the experts please note that he said, ‘There should be a choice rather than a single policy of deinstitutionalisation.’ The editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of Monday, 30 May 2005 commented on the New South Wales Auditor-General’s report on emergency services. It said that, if an acute mentally ill bed is needed, the wait is ‘longer than for other medical patients’. It continues: Some have to be transferred long distances to be admitted, hardly helping their recovery. Others are treated in emergency departments, with all the attendant disruption and misdirection of resources that that involves. Others still-about 9 per cent-never even get that far. They just get sick of waiting and simply leave. What happens to them? It is no idle question. The Cornelia Rau case shows the dire consequences which can follow the community’s neglect of the mentally ill. MAIN COMMITTEE That says more about our mental health policy than it does about our immigration policy. I want to say at this point that it is not only hospital emergency departments and immigration officials that have to deal with people similar to Ms Rau who are suffering an illness. Often it is the police who have to put their lives on the line when the acute mentally ill have armed themselves or are otherwise threatening violence. Police officers’ lives and careers can be traumatically affected by the consequences of a decision that they must make in a split second. As well as police, prison officers are affected. For many disturbed people, our jails have replaced the closed mental residential care centres. This is in part the effect of reducing over a period of several decades the number of acute care beds to 10 per cent of their former establishment. The editorial goes on: More mentally ill patients are turning up to emergency departments now than ever before, they are sicker, and more of them have to be admitted to hospital. The 24,000 patients admitted to acute care beds in 2003-04 represented an increase of 11 per cent over the previous three years. Unfortunately, the mental health professional establishment and the National Mental Health Strategy are bent on reducing what is left of institutional care. They are dismissive of it as the old service model of beds and buildings. I do not wish to be unfriendly towards the professionals, because I do acknowledge their expertise and their genuine commitment, but it has to be said that in my observation and in the opinion of many carers they are obsessed with a 1960s antipathy towards institutional care for the acute mentally ill. In a submission to the Senate this year the Mental Health Council of Australia said this about the achievements of the National Mental Health Strategy: the number of stand alone psychiatric beds has decreased by 60% since 1993. So, according to the mental health professionals, the first ‘achievement’ of the Mental Health Strategy has been to reduce the number of stand-alone psychiatric beds in Australia. Instead of the 60 per cent decrease in stand-alone psychiatric beds being trumpeted as an achievement, there should have been a doubling of the number. The Mental Health Council went on to say: Reduced reliance on stand alone psychiatric hospitals was the major policy driver for the first National Mental Health Strategy. They apparently believe that it has been successful because ‘dedicated, stand-alone mental institutions are regarded as a last-case resort’. However, on behalf of the carers in my electorate and in the general community, let me tell the chamber that dedicated, stand-alone mental institutions are not the last resort for the acutely mentally ill; to date, they are the only humane solution for those who suffer an acute mental illness. The Mental Health Council then goes on to sayMs HallMr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene. a question? Ms Hall-All right. We might have a talk later, because I am interested. ... while the institutions themselves have closed, institutionalisation of people with a mental illness has in fact been transferred to prison and detention systems or replaced with isolation within the community, for example through homelessness. MAIN COMMITTEE
