speaker: Mrs Vale
theText: I am happy to do that. The Mental Health Council then went on to say:If you shut down the institutions, what else can you expect? However, the closure of more residential institutional care centres is being proposed by the received wisdom of the mental health professionals. In response to the non-existent services in some parts of rural Australia, they are proposing that existing funding for acute care beds be distributed in accordance with population densities and to address unmet needs in rural and growth areas. It should be noted that it is the existing funding for acute care beds that is proposed to be redistributed, not an increase in funding for acute care beds in rural and new areas. They want to reduce the number of beds in existing residential care centres. With all due respect, may I say that, in light of the demand, this is a crazy proposal. From what I can gather, the problem seems to be that mental health professionals, as I have said before, are obsessed with the possible abuse of human rights in mental health care facilities if residential care centres are restored. I believe that in today’s world there is a defeatist attitude of the highest order. I believe that we can have quality mental health residential care centres that are humane and are without the human rights abuses that occurred in some cases in the past. I believe that the successful residential care centres that can be observed in the aged care sector provide an excellent model that could be followed in caring for the acutely mentally ill. It is not rocket science. Despite the cut and thrust of politics, the standard of aged care has improved significantly in our country in recent years. Senior citizens who reside in aged care hostels are residents in their own right. Some are owners of their hostel units. They are not cooped up in a house with five others; they have room to move. They can remain in company if they wish or go off to some other parts of their modern facility or its maintained gardens if they wish to be alone. They have available for their use dedicated recreational facilities and programs. Because of the larger numbers, there is a better staff-to-resident ratio, with consequent better services and resourcing opportunities. They are residents; they are not inmates. AlthoughI have had some hard things to say about the views that have come through the Mental Health Council of Australia, to their credit they argue for about $1 billion per year over the next 10 years to be put into primary and secondary community care, together with the matching of any increases from the states. They highlight the problem and they are about boosting community care in order to reduce the pressure on facilities for the acutely mentally ill. I do not know whether the $1 billion-plus per year level of expenditure is sustainable into the future, but my plea is: do not do it by further reducing and badmouthing residential care facilities for the acutely mentally ill. Learn from the mistakes of the past. Acknowledge the inhumanity that was and still is being inflicted on the vulnerable and powerless because of deinstitutionalisation. Do not shoot, by closing more doors, the acutely mentally ill messenger, who desperately needs more appropriate care. Do not thrust the acutely mentally ill onto their unresourced families and say, in effect, ‘This is your problem. Here’s a form to apply for a couple of dollars.’ My concern is that the problem of mental illness has now grown and will grow further, to the point where it is beyond the financial resources that are needed and will be needed on a sustained basis. We have to address the mental health problem before the primary stage. The deluge of mental illness has got to this stage because we have been in denial about the things MAIN COMMITTEE that can contribute to mental illness. As a community we have done what is easy and convenient. The mentally ill have always been with us but their number has soared in recent decades. We have to have a close look at prevention. Family breakdown is known to facilitate great distress and contribute to depression amongst the young. It may release one or both parents to get on with a new life, but for some children it has a lingering and traumatic effect. Many blame themselves for the family breakdown and suffer emotionally for the rest of their lives. In some cases, family breakdown leaves a trail of many traumas, including child sexual abuse, youth homelessness and suicide. Research has shown that this is a major cause of mental illness. An increasing number of people are suffering dysfunctional and sometimes fatal psychotic disorders as a result of smoking cannabis and using other banned substances. Harm minimisation drug strategies over the eighties and nineties tended, if not to glorify, then to present an image of toleration of illicit drugs, and the legalisation of cannabis for personal use in some states has been a mental health disaster. We now know that substance abuse is a significant cause of youth mental illness. It is only now, with the greater availability of abortion, that its emotional consequences are beginning to surface. The evidence is now beginning to mount about post-abortion trauma that contributes to severe depression in some women. Of course, there are many other important causes of mental illness and depression, but these are just some that have come to mind. In an article in the Age dated 11 April 2004, Professor Allan Fels said, when speaking of his daughter: Unlike many, Isabella has a family that both cares and is in the privileged position of being able to afford to buy better care. Those without such family or financial support are abandoned by a system that doesn’t respond or doesn’t care. He went on to conclude: Although we have had national mental health reform for more than a decade, the experience of the mentally ill and their families is of little genuine progress. As a community, our future health and welfare may well depend on our capacity to respond to the challenges of mental health and well-being. Our present approach of leaving families to cope, largely unseen and largely through their own devices, reflects poorly on our nation. Robbing Peter-in this case, residential care centres-to underpay Paul-in this case, community based care-is not the answer. Blaming institutional care for the mental health delivery problem is just plain wrong. We need to finetune the Richmond and Burdekin strategies in the light of several decades of experience of only doing half of what they recommended and recognise the importance of adequate and good residential care models for the acutely mentally ill while at the same time building better community care. We could effectively adopt the current aged care hostel model for residential care and make it available to the acutely mentally ill. Finally, we could look at broader policies in the community that will help us avoid the consequences of mental illness. I commend this bill to the House. has decided to move back from the digital age. I notice we have gone back to Swiss clocks, as opposed to the ones with digital formats we had previously, which I must say I had no problems with. MAIN COMMITTEE

theText: Let me just make the observation that this chambermittee. partments) Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and other appropriation bills. During the Treasurer’s budget speech, he announced new tax thresholds to take effect from 1 July 2005. I am not going to go over what those thresholds are. But what I think is worth talking about is the view that we have adopted in the Labor Party, which is that we believe that the tax cut proposals from the government are unfair. We are not arguing that there should not be tax cuts-let me make that very clear. What we are saying is that, for the majority of the Australian work force, the tax cuts are minuscule. If a person earns less than $55,000 a year, the maximum tax cut they will receive under the government’s proposals will be $6 a week. If they happen to be on $15,000 a year, it is only $3.50. Many people in that tax bracket probably will not pay tax, but the bottom line is that what we have here is a structure that distorts the needs of the Australian community. In my own electorate of Lingiari, 80 per cent of wage and salary earners earn less than $1,000 a week. This means that 80 per cent of those people will receive a maximum tax cut of six bucks a week-enough money to buy a sandwich and a milkshake. As one of my colleagues said yesterday, it is hardly enough to get you a pie and a beer if you are down at the footy at the McG. I know that, in the case of Traeger Park, you would not do any better. Traeger Park is the main oval in Alice Springs, where there is a very good football competition. At the other end of the salary scale, wage earners who earn $1,500 a week or more will benefit by at least $27 a week. If they happen to be members of parliament, who earn in excess of $100,000 a year, they will receive a huge tax cut around $45 or $50 a week. I do not believe that is either fair or reasonable. In the Lingiari electorate, approximately four per cent of wage and salary earners will earn $1,500 a week or more. We note that other electorates are more fortunate. While only four per cent of workers in my electorate will benefit by the tax cut of $27 a week or more, 10 per cent of people in the Prime Minister’s own electorate will get that benefit. In my budget reply last year, I spoke about the electorate of North Sydney. I mentioned that 90 per cent of Lingiari individual tax payers missed out on tax cuts. In North Sydney the figure was 65 per cent. That was the case last year. This year, I notice that, in the North Sydney seat of the minister responsible for human services, 20 per cent of wage and salary earners earn more than $1,500 a week and will benefit substantially from the tax cuts. This is not saying that we do not have a progressive tax system. It is saying that those who most need the maximum tax break are low-income earners on less than $55,000 a year. It seems to me that it is only fair and reasonable that we, as a community, examine what our priorities ought to be. Should our priority be to give an extra 40 or 50 bucks to members of parliament or should it be to give a better deal to those people and families who earn less than $55,000 a year? I know what I think should happen. I would be happy, in my own case, to have this situation reversed. speaker: Mr Snowdon
theText: Except in here. We are discussing Appropriation (Parliamentary Detax cuts at the upper level so they are not as gross for those people who earn maximum incomes. It seems to me that, despite the rhetoric that comes from the government from time to time, that is an entirely appropriate course of action. It will say to the Australian community that, while we know the government is going to give us this tax cut of six bucks a week, and while we know this will happen after 1 July, no matter what the opposition does in the parliament, we appreciate the intent of the Labor Party to ensure that we get a better benefit than that which is being proposed by the government. You know the electorate of Lingiari, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley. You have been through it; certainly you have been to the north-west of Western Australia any number of times. You would recognise the disproportionate costs that people in these areas bear in terms of living. They pay for their remoteness; they pay for it very materially in the higher cost of food and the higher cost of fuel. These sorts of things are what we regard as everyday needs. Six bucks in that environment does not go very far. In most instances, while it will provide welcome additional income to most families, it will not be sufficient to shift the burden that has been placed upon them by a series of government decisions over the last little while-for example, increasing the cost of private health insurance and increasing house mortgages. Quickly this $6 will be eaten up. That is why we in the Labor Party say we should double that. The government should adopt our proposition of doing these tax cuts differently, giving a greater deal, a better deal, to those people on low incomes, with us at the top end of the income bracket saying, ‘Well, that’s not unreasonable; that’s a good thing to do.’ We understand that families are struggling and we could hardly say we suffer from the same pressure on our family budgets-even though, in my case, we have a huge number of kids. There are families with an equivalent number of children who earn $55,000 a year or less. I think it is a bloody disgrace, frankly, that we should be countenancing pocketing our 40 or 50 bucks and giving these poor Australians $6 a week. I have spoken in the past in this place about the cost of living in remote communities, but-leaving aside our differences over the tax issue-this budget shows me that this government has no comprehension whatsoever of the needs of regional Australia, particularly remote Australia. It has no understanding-that would be the polite way of putting it-at all of the costs and needs of those communities. I have spoken in this place before about the plight of roads in the bush. Once again, the budget has let us down. The government talks about the need for infrastructure expenditure, but, once again, it has not addressed the infrastructure needs of Northern Australia. There are between 8,000 and 9,000 kilometres of unincorporated roads in the Northern Territory alone. These are largely used by the beef industry, the mining industry, the tourism industry and small communities. It is a severe cost to business and to those community members to travel on those roads. With great respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I notice we have in the chamber two members of the National Party, you and one of your colleagues. You understand, I am certain, the cost of transporting beef in road trains over large distances on bad dirt roads. Who bears that cost? Ultimately, the consumer, but directly bearing the cost in the first instance are the road transport industry and the beef producers. I would have thought that, in the context of making MAIN COMMITTEE our industries more efficient, it would not be beyond the wit and wisdom of this government to recognise that, if you want to increase productivity and efficiency in the bush-the real bush; not up and down here on the east coast-you should address those infrastructure shortfalls. But do we get that from the government? No way. Instead we get a very distorted allocation of resources through the Roads to Recovery program. Where does that money go? Of course, in the pockets of National Party seats-and principally that of the member for Gwydir, I might say. In my communities we know the costs that are involved in not addressing this issue. A range of issues confront people who live in the bush, like roads and communication. The government is still going to sell Telstra. You chaps in the National Party understand-you particularly, my friend, Member for Hinkler-the telecommunication needs of people in the bush. In my communities people are underserviced and underresourced. That is not because Telstra Country Wide are not doing their job. In fact, I have nothing but the highest of praise for the Telstra Country Wide people who work in the Northern Territory. But they are subject to budget decisions made by a board. The majority of the decision-making power rests with the government, as the majority shareholder. The board has made decisions which will ensure that there will be no catch-up. Despite the protestations of the government, blind Freddy knows what future-proofing means: ‘We’ll give you a set of standards which we think will work at the time, even though we know you’re behind the eight ball already. You’ll never get to catch up and you’ll never get an equivalent standard of service to people who live in the major metropolitan regions.’ That is what will happen. So we get a major communications disadvantage for people who live in the bush. That is not something which I think is acceptable, and I know it is not acceptable to the people of Lingiari. We deserve and we want something better from this government. The people of Lingiari are the poorest of Australians. However, there are pockets of wealth in Lingiari. There is a large mining operation in Groote Eylandt, and there is wealth at Nhulunbuy and Ranger. There is a lot of wealth being developed, and a lot of taxes are being paid to the government, like company tax. There are a lot of export earnings coming into the Australian community. But we are not getting investment back in those communities or in that region by this government. It is about time we actually got a fair shake. The bulk of the population who live in this community, 44 per cent or thereabouts of the voters in my communities, are Indigenous. They are at the very bottom end of the income scale. They live mostly in abject poverty. I will address this at another time. They are not regarded as being important enough to get the finances that are required to address their poverty needs. We heard the Prime Minister down at the reconciliation conference talking about how he wants to address Aboriginal disadvantage, Indigenous disadvantage, in this country, to meet Indigenous Australians halfway. He could start by addressing the major indicators of poverty. He could start by addressing the $800 million shortfall in Aboriginal housing in the Northern Territory alone, where communities have 17 and 20 people living per house. He goes on about the need for education. As I have said in this place on many occasions, you have to address the health of the whole person and the whole community. That means looking at all those indicators: health, housing, education, primary health care and environmental health. MAIN COMMITTEE All of these things cost money. We are seeing no benchmarking by this government of what it is proposing to introduce to these communities to ensure they get out of this poverty. We get a lot of platitudes and a lot of mutual responsibility, but no acceptance by the government of its responsibility to provide these Indigenous Australians with the rights that every other Australian would regard as fundamental to their living. These are rights which they should have, human rights, rights which are accorded to them by conventions which we are signatory to-a right to education, a right to housing, a right to employment opportunities-fundamental human rights which this government has failed to properly address. Instead, it talks about penalising people. It is about time we got rid of the penalties and started accepting our responsibilities as a nation to address their most vital needs. In the few moments I have left, I want to remind the House that, of course, there is an election about to happen in the Northern Territory, on 18 June. The election will involve the Country Liberal Party, a conservative party which has two members sitting in this place, one with the National Party and one with the Liberal Party, I understand. They cannot make up their minds who they are. But we know they are not a Territory party. not sit with either of them, would they? They might vote with them, but they would not sit with them. But they do. Their comrades-confreres, I might describe them as-in the Northern Territory are seeking election on 18 June, having left office in 2001 after being defeated by the Labor Party. I have to say: that was a great moment in time, one of those moments of history. I was asked to be one of the experts sitting on the ABC panel on the night of the election. We saw those results coming in. I was with Kerry O’Brien, Antony Green and Barry Coulter-who, I am sure some of you will know, was formerly the Deputy Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Barry was sitting alongside me, Kerry O’Brien was sitting over here and Antony Green was sitting over there. Within 20 minutes, I had the biggest smile. Within 20 minutes of the numbers coming in, I was able to say, ‘I think we’re going to win this. We’ve got these six seats; it will be a Labor victory.’ You should have seen their faces. Do you know why there was a Labor victory? Because the CLP had done a bad job. The CLP then left the Northern Territory with a budget black hole of $127 million, which it did not disclose to the Northern Territory community prior to the election. It is a very different kettle of fish now because the current Northern Territory government is providing a capacity for the government to adhere to a fiscal strategy, to sit in budget 2005, which will ensure that its budget is balanced by 2008-09. The Northern Territory government will make its commitments available to Treasury to be assessed to ensure they will meet that objective. It is inviting the CLP to do the same thing, to have a bit of transparency before polling day to show what the true costs of their promises will be to the Northern Territory community in terms of their budget. We know from past performance what the likely outcome of that will be: there will be no cooperation. They hate transparency and they want to try and hide from the Northern Territory community. I am sure that the Labor Party will be returned and that the CLP will not be returned. I would hazard a guess that that is going to create all sorts of havoc. speaker: Mr Snowdon
theText: It is a matter of choice. If they were really a Territory party, they wouldabout whether to go to the National Party party room or the Liberal Party party room? What do they do? They do not represent the interests of the Northern Territory if they are doing that. If they masquerade as the CLP, they should be sitting as the CLP in Canberra and not sitting with either of you guys. (Time expired) Sitting suspended from 1.29 pm to 4.03 pm 2005-2006 and the cognate appropriation bills. In doing so, I would like to compliment the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Dr Brendan Nelson, on some of the advancements and general improvements to be found in this budget. As the member for Kalgoorlie, I remind members that the electorate of Kalgoorlie takes up 91 per cent of the Western Australian landmass and by definition, therefore, it has a most sparsely distributed population. There are some 250 communities, approximately, spread across that 2.3 million square kilometres. When I speak in this place, I speak for genuine regional Australia. Any improvement in the education budget that reflects opportunity for regional and remote Australia is of interest to me, because it is of interest to my constituents. In the 2005-06 budget, the Australian government provides an estimated $28.4 million under the Country Areas Program which will benefit Australian schools and students in rural and remote communities. This is good news. It represents an estimated increase of $6.6 million, or 24 per cent over the previous year, to government and non-government education authorities. Of this $28.4 million, an estimated $23.9 million will be provided to state government schools and an estimated $4.5 million will be provided to Catholic and independent schools. The Australian government recognises that students attending primary and secondary schools in geographically isolated areas often have a more limited access to educational opportunities than do metropolitan students. Isn’t that nice? The Australian government funds for CAP are provided to state and Northern Territory government and non-government schools. The funds are used to support projects which enhance the curriculum through excursions, visits, and attendance at cultural and sporting events; to assist with the transition to further education, training or work; and to provide access to professional development for teachers. In addition to those changes, from 2005 the Australian government has significantly increased assistance under the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme, the AIC. That scheme helps the families of primary and secondary students and tertiary students who are under 16 years old who are unable to attend an appropriate government school on a daily basis primarily because of geographic isolation. The basic boarding allowance and the distance education allowance both received a significant boost from 1 January 2005. The basic boarding allowance increased from $4,446 to $6,000 per year from 1 January 2005 and will help around 7,500 students who have no choice other than to board away from home at a school, hostel or private home. This results in an estimated increase in funding of over $39.6 million over the four years to 2008-09. The distance education allowance increased to $3,000 per year for students who study at home through distance education. The increase-some $1,759 for a primary school student and $1,140 for a secondary student in 2005-reflects the increased cost of new computer technology and communications infrastructure required by students. This results in an estimated increase in funding of $21.3 million over the four years to 2008-09. MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Haase (Kalgoorlie) (4.03 Pm)
theText: TodayI am speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1)The second-home allowance and the additional boarding allowance increased by the CPI from the beginning of 2005. Also, from 1 July 2005, the Australian government will extend eligibility for youth allowance, Austudy and Abstudy payments to eligible full-time new apprentices, who will be able to apply for the same payments currently available to full-time students. This will assist them in the early years of their new apprenticeship, when their wages are generally at their lowest. But my main concern today is not the wonderful increases to government funding for rural and remote education, increases which are seriously and greatly appreciated; it is to highlight the fact that inequities still apply. I have a great concern in particular with the inequities that exist in the allocation of and entitlement to youth allowance. WhatI will endeavour to do today is to point out the contrast between a rural based family having a child who is of tertiary education age and about to leave secondary college, and a city family in exactly the same situation. My proposition is that the rural family, by the nature of their employment, happen to earn more than the allowable ceiling. To start with, the allowable ceiling is $28,850 per annum for the earnings of a family, if they are going to be entitled to the full entitlement of youth allowance for their son or daughter attending a tertiary institution away from their home. The Youth Allowance program is primarily designed to support young people, but it ought to include country families whose means may be above the current threshold but whose income is not sufficient to enable them to rent or buy a metropolitan unit for their children to attend university. By making youth allowance available to this demographic, not only will the additional costs traditionally shouldered by country students be alleviated but a greater equity in access to educational opportunities will also be achieved. I commonly hear from families of country students who have no choice but to meet practically all of the costs of independent living for their child, while city families merely hand over a few bus or train fares. If the high level of parental support is not available, accessing youth allowance for a regional student will entail at least a year of full-time work so that he or she can be classed as independent. Compare this to city students, who have the option of going straight to university, comfortable in the knowledge that they can live with their parents for as long as required or desired-or, possibly, permitted. In terms of access to youth allowance, the parameters of independence represent an anomaly. Students from the city can be classified as independent when in fact it is regardless of whether they live at home or not; whereas, a student from the country has to leave home to study. If they have not taken a gap year to earn eligibility for independence, they do not qualify for youth allowance. This means that a city student can be eligible for youth allowance whilst living at home, whereas a country student has no such luxury. Compounding this inequity is the fact that these payments can be spent on socialising-and are very often spent on socialising-and mere discretionary expenditure. By comparison, country students living in the city have to make ends meet and almost always have a part-time job to cover extra living expenses that youth allowance does not cover. The amount for independence must be earned in 18 months. Therefore, the student does not receive payments until halfway through the first year of study. They must rely on their parents’ income or part-time work to cover their living costs in the first five months, a difficult task when studying full time, with some of the biggest expenses, such as books and general MAIN COMMITTEE setting-up fees, presenting themselves during the first semester. A student can easily be left having no means by which to pay for them. Further, as most university courses cannot be deferred for more than a year, if a student needs youth allowance while studying, and is not eligible due to his or her family’s means, they cannot participate in programs like Rotary Exchange, or even take that gap year off to travel, because there is a need to spend a year and a half earning the money to shore up their ability to pursue tertiary education. I note that there is assistance available to children under 16 under the Isolated Children scheme, as I have just mentioned. It seems reasonable to me, because of the inequities I have pointed up, that this provision be extended to older tertiary students if they are from country areas where they are not able to live at home whilst accessing tertiary education. This was certainly the case for my own children in Karratha, where we lived for 20 years. Like hundreds of families in my electorate, I experienced first-hand this inequity. It is part and parcel of country students pursuing a tertiary education. It is with these hundreds of families in mind that I rise today to underline this anomaly to the House. We are doing a great deal and achieving a great deal in this area, but still the inequities exist. In the 2000-01 budget we changed the situation so that from 1 January 2001 the government would disregard 75 per cent of the value of a family’s interest in assets such as a farm or business. We changed that from the allowable 50 per cent, increasing the eligibility or the number of those that would be eligible for youth allowance. Those changes, although they are greatly appreciated, simply do not go far enough. I say again that the federal Youth Allowance system aims to support young people financially if they are unable to completely support themselves. But, with the anomalies that exist, eligibility for the allowance is very difficult to attain. Parents must have a very low income for their children to be automatically eligible for the allowance. As I have said, young people must work for 18 months and earn $15,950 in that period to be declared independent. The strict limitations on that allowance make it very difficult for students from regional areas who must leave home to study. Obviously they require some form of financial assistance if their family has an income which is above the minimum threshold for eligibility but is unable to support their child. Young people are then forced to take at least that year off from study to become eligible. The current system states that, unless the annual family income is below the threshold for automatic youth allowance, students intending to study higher education must either rely on their parents for assistance during their course or work for that 18 months and earn the required amount. When you analyse the very restrictive, very narrow terms that make that allowance absolutely available, it becomes obvious that a large number of issues highlight the anomaly and increase the frustration of the families and students that find themselves in this situation. If the regional students’ parents cannot support them, or if they already receive a youth allowance, country students must take at least a year off and earn the money for the independence. Alternatively, city students have the option of going straight to university. The comfort that they gain from living with their parents simply highlights, once again, the anomaly that exists. Country students are not able to have their university places held for more than 12 months. This is yet another hurdle in the road for a country student to achieve that diploma or that graduation certificate from a tertiary institution. MAIN COMMITTEE The youth allowance payment is not enough to cover college fees. College is an option taken by country students in order to meet new people and have the comfort of acclimatising with more ease to a city situation. That city environment is often most alien to country students. Unless they have the opportunity of the camaraderie that is offered by a university campus college, the achievement of that tertiary education is made more difficult than it ought to be. Because the youth allowance payment, if they are entitled to it, is not enough to cover college fees, the students need to work 10 to 15 hours a week in order to cover the fees. But the system does not allow students to earn more than $118 per week. As a result, the student does not have anywhere near enough funds to live a reasonable existence. If a country student is awarded a scholarship for course fees, they must attend university or TAFE the year after high school graduation. Scholarships cannot be deferred. These students are not supported for living costs and therefore must either rely on their parents for support or reject the scholarship and spend that year working to entitle them, eventually, to a youth allowance. It is an unfair burden, as I have said, for parents to have to support the living costs of their offspring at university or TAFE. It is often much more than the family can afford. It is not reasonable to suggest that a family income of $28,850, which is in excess of that allowedthe base limit that starts to disqualify payment of that youth allowance is as low as $28,850infers that these families are from some great wealth belt and can set up a son or daughter in a metropolitan or other area where they may attend a tertiary institution that exists. It costs a great deal of money. They will have to meet a weekly rental fee and will have to do something about the cost of food. Many people see that, in the long-term cost effectiveness, they have to go into a mortgage situation and purchase some sort of real estate in the metropolitan area to accommodate their student child. There is ample evidence to suggest that country families do not need this additional hazard to remain loyal residents of regional Australia. In my 2.3 million square kilometres, I have but one centre-Broome, in the Kimberleythat has an increasing population. All the rest are declining. They are declining because of the tendency to empty out rural centres and migrate to city centres; if not city then certainly coastal. This is causing a problem. I am often heard to say that if we allow it to continue to happen we will have the eventuality that when Australians from the leafy suburbs decide to have their once a year, or once a lifetime, sojourn to the outback they will find no-one left to pour the beer or the petrol. It will change, for all time, their impression of the wonderful outback of Australia that has been so much our heritage. I have, for six years now, contemplated solutions to the demise of populations in the bush. In this place, I have spoken frequently on the topic. I have illustrated today just one hurdle that exists for families residing in rural areas-that is, the inequity that exists for a family that does not qualify for youth allowance in a rural area, in comparison with one that exists in the city and has all that public infrastructure in place to assist them. The main solution, as I see it, is a dramatic increase in the taxation zone rebate system that was introduced back in 1945 and has undergone, for the last 10 years, no reasonable review or increase. I call again on my government-my Treasurer-to seriously consider the increase in taxation zone rebates and do something now to change the situation of hurdles in the bush. the government’s budget for 2005-06. It is now three weeks since the Treasurer brought down his 10th, and the Prime Minister’s 16th, budget. This budget does not serve Australia well. It MAIN COMMITTEE
